var_drug_ann.Notes: c.1679T>G (DPYD*13, rs55886062) carriers had significantly lower pretreatment DPD enzyme activity as measured by the dihydrouracil/uracil ([UH2]/[U]) plasma ratio; association p-values reported in Fig. 1 (***P < 0.001 or ****P < 0.0001 versus wild-type). Low [UH2]/[U] ≤10 was used to define partial DPD deficiency, which predicts impaired 5-fluorouracil clearance and higher systemic exposure.
var_drug_ann.Sentence: Genotype carriers of the rs55886062 variant allele are associated with decreased dihydrouracil/uracil ([UH2]/[U]) plasma ratio of 5-fluorouracil in patients eligible for uracil analog-based chemotherapy as compared to DPYD wild-type (*1/*1) genotypes.
Citations: “Dose adjustment based on pretreatment screening for the most clinically relevant *DPYD* defective variants, i.e. c.1679T>G (*DPYD*13*, rs55886062), c.1905+1G>A (*DPYD*2A*, rs3918290) and c.2846A>T (p.Asp949Val or rs67376798), has been shown to improve the safety of chemotherapy regimens based on fluorouracil [29]. Accordingly, international recommendations now provide indications for drug-related genetic tests and *DPYD* genotype-guided dosing in routine clinical practice [17, 18]. As expected, our data showed a significant association between each of these genetic variants and low DPD activity (Fig. 1).”

“Box plot showing DPD pretreatment activity assessed by the dihydrouracil/uracil ([UH2]/[U]) plasma ratio according to the patient genotype. … The red dash line indicates the ratio threshold used to categorize patients as having partial DPD deficiency (ratio ≤10) or normal DPD activity (ratio>10). n = number of patients; ***P < 0.001; ****P < 0.0001.”

“Dihydropyrimidine dehydrogenase (DPD), the initial and rate limiting enzyme involved in the catabolism of 5-fluorouracil (5-FU), is responsible for the elimination of 80–85% of the administered dose. Plasma concentrations of uracil ([U]), the endogenous substrate for DPD, or its product dihydrouracil (UH2) are routinely used as a surrogate marker for systemic DPD activity [14]. Indeed, pretreatment [U] and [UH2]/[U] ratio are highly correlated with systemic DPD activity and many studies have shown a relationship between fluoropyrimidine-induced toxicity and a DPD phenotype characterized by high [U] or low [UH2]/[U] ratio [14, 15].”

This splice donor variant is a well-established loss-of-function allele leading to impaired 5-fluorouracil catabolism and increased fluoropyrimidine exposure.

“Indeed, according to PharmGKB, more than 20 loss-of-function *DPYD* variants have been reported to alter DPD enzymatic activity, and consequently patients harboring such variants are exposed to an increased risk of severe toxicity when receiving standard dose of fluoropyrimidine. For this reason, international guidelines now recommend pre-emptive *DPYD* genotyping for several clinically relevant defective variants: i.e., c.1905+1G>A (*DPYD*2A*), c.1679T>G (*DPYD*13*), c.2846A>T, and Haplotype B3 (c.1236G>A or c.1129–5923C>G) as well as genotype-guided prescribing recommendations [17, 18].”

var_drug_ann.Notes: c.2846A>T (p.Asp949Val, rs67376798) was significantly associated with low pretreatment DPD activity based on [UH2]/[U] ratio (Fig. 1), indicating reduced 5-fluorouracil catabolism and increased risk of elevated systemic exposure; dose adjustment for this variant is recommended in existing guidelines.

As expected, our data showed a significant association between each of these genetic variants and low DPD activity (Fig. [1](#Fig1)).

Specifically, our results confirmed the strong impact of the three clinically rare variants. PMC10786722.summary:
Purpose
To quantify how much rare DPYD variants contribute to dihydropyrimidine dehydrogenase (DPD) deficiency, and to evaluate whether next‑generation sequencing (NGS)–based DPYD profiling could improve prediction of fluoropyrimidine toxicity beyond conventional testing for a few guideline variants.

Design and methods
- Retrospective single‑center study of 2,972 adults scheduled for fluoropyrimidine-based chemotherapy.
- DPD phenotype was measured pre‑treatment using plasma uracil [U] and the dihydrouracil/uracil ratio ([UH2]/[U]) by UPLC–MS/MS.
  - Partial DPD deficiency: [UH2]/[U] ≤ 10; complete deficiency: [UH2]/[U] ≤ 1 (none observed).
  - Alternative thresholds based on [U] alone (≥16 µg/mL for partial deficiency, ≥150 µg/mL for complete) were also assessed.
- DPYD was sequenced by amplicon-based NGS (MiSeq) covering all exons and splice junctions; very rare/novel variants were Sanger-confirmed.
- Variants were annotated with SIFT, PolyPhen-2, CADD; rare variants were defined as MAF <1% (very rare ≤0.1%).
- Statistics: non-parametric tests comparing [UH2]/[U] across genotypes; enrichment analyses for variant classes in deficient vs normal phenotypes.

Key cohort and phenotyping findings
- 19.7% (580/2,972) of patients had partial DPD deficiency by [UH2]/[U] ≤ 10; no complete deficiency detected.
- Using both [U] and [UH2]/[U] identified 21.1% (628/2,972) as DPD deficient, but concordance between the two markers at standard cut‑offs was low (only 114 patients overlapped):
  - Many patients had low [UH2]/[U] but [U] <16 ng/mL, and vice versa.
  - The data suggest currently recommended thresholds for [U] and [UH2]/[U] do not classify deficiency equivalently; [UH2]/[U] ≤ 10 labels more patients as partially deficient.

Genetic findings
- In DPD‑deficient group (n=580):
  - 134 were DPYD wild-type; 446 carried ≥1 variant (208 with 1, 238 with >1), totaling 809 variants.
  - 30 distinct variants: 7 common (MAF ≥1%), 23 rare/very rare/novel (MAF <1%); 13/23 rare variants predicted deleterious.
  - Variant types: 77% missense, 1 nonsense, 1 indel, 2 canonical splice, 3 synonymous.
- In phenotypically normal group (n=2,392):
  - 623 wild-type; 1,769 with variants (831 with 1, 938 with >1), totaling 3,183 variants.
  - 58 distinct variants: 7 common, 51 rare/very rare/novel; 18/51 rare variants predicted deleterious.
  - Variant types: 55% missense, 2 nonsense, 2 indels, 6 canonical splice, 17 synonymous, 1 UTR.
- All rare variants were heterozygous. Assumed predominantly European ancestry.

Association of guideline DPYD variants with DPD activity
- Classic high-risk variants (all heterozygous in this cohort):
  - c.1905+1G>A (*DPYD*2A, rs3918290; splice donor).
  - c.1679T>G (*DPYD*13, rs55886062; Ile560Ser).
  - c.2846A>T (rs67376798; Asp949Val).
- Each showed a strong, highly significant reduction in [UH2]/[U] compared with noncarriers, confirming their major functional impact and supporting existing CPIC/EMA guideline recommendations for genotype‑guided dose reduction.

Association of common DPYD variants
Seven common variants (MAF ≥1%) were evaluated; three showed modest but significant associations with lower [UH2]/[U]:
- c.1236G>A (rs56038477; p.Glu412Glu; hapB3 component) – consistent with prior evidence of partial DPD deficiency.
- c.496A>G (rs2297595; p.Met166Val).
- c.2194G>A (rs1801160; *DPYD*6; p.Val732Ile).
The effect sizes on DPD activity were much smaller than for *2A, *13 and c.2846A>T, raising questions about their standalone clinical utility for dose adjustment.

Burden and impact of rare/very rare DPYD variants
- Rare variants (MAF <1%) were significantly enriched in partially DPD-deficient patients compared to those with normal activity:
  - Any rare variant: 9.3% in deficient vs 3.2% in normal; p < 1×10⁻⁵.
  - After excluding *2A, *13 and c.2846A>T: 4.5% vs 2.6%; p < 0.03.
- When restricting to rare variants predicted deleterious by CADD >15 and excluding the classic high‑risk alleles:
  - 4.2% of deficient vs 1.6% of normal patients carried such variants (p < 0.001).
- These findings indicate that:
  - A sizable fraction of patients with low DPD activity carry rare, likely functional DPYD alleles that are not captured by standard 4‑variant clinical panels.
  - Rare variants contribute measurably to interindividual variability in DPD activity and thus to fluoropyrimidine toxicity risk.

Interpretation and implications for pharmacogenomics
- Phenotyping vs genotyping:
  - Uracil-based phenotyping ([U], [UH2]/[U]) shows substantial methodological and threshold-related variability and imperfect concordance.
  - Genotype-based prediction of DPD activity with established high‑risk DPYD variants is robust and clinically validated; however, it misses many functionally impaired individuals.
- Rare-variant contribution:
  - Consistent with broader pharmacogenomic data showing that >90% of pharmacogene variation is rare, this study demonstrates that rare DPYD variants are significantly enriched in phenotypic DPD deficiency.
  - Approximately one half of the rare variants detected had in silico evidence of deleteriousness (high CADD, damaging SIFT/PolyPhen), and these clustered more frequently in patients with low [UH2]/[U].
- Clinical implication:
  - Limiting testing to the four guideline variants (*2A, *13, c.2846A>T, hapB3) improves safety but leaves a non-trivial residual risk because additional rare loss‑of‑function or deleterious missense alleles remain undetected.
  - Comprehensive DPYD sequencing (exons + splice sites) integrated with an interpretation framework (e.g., CADD >15 plus functional data as they accumulate) would better stratify risk and more accurately predict DPD phenotype.
  - Such NGS-based genotyping could be combined with phenotyping to create a more sensitive and specific pre‑treatment screen for fluoropyrimidine dose individualization.

Limitations
- No direct toxicity data: the study links DPYD variation to a biochemical/phenotypic marker ([UH2]/[U]) but not to observed clinical fluoropyrimidine toxicity or outcomes.
- Single-center, mostly European cohort; ancestry-specific variant spectra and effect sizes may differ in non‑European populations.
- Functional effects of most rare variants were inferred from in silico tools, not from in vitro enzyme assays.

Authors’ conclusions
- Rare and very rare DPYD variants substantially contribute to interindividual variability in DPD enzyme activity.
- Current limited DPYD genotyping panels are insufficient to identify all patients at high risk for fluoropyrimidine toxicity.
- The authors advocate incorporating NGS-based comprehensive DPYD sequencing—including rare variants—into routine pre‑emptive pharmacogenetic testing, ideally in combination with phenotyping, to optimize safety of 5‑FU and capecitabine without compromising efficacy.

For practice and guideline development
- Supports ongoing movement from “4-variant DPYD panels” toward broader sequencing-based pharmacogenomics for fluoropyrimidines.
- Suggests that rare-variant burden or curated variant lists (leveraging resources like PharmVar/PharmGKB) may need to be integrated into future CPIC/EMA recommendations.
- Highlights the need for prospective, toxicity-linked studies to validate which specific rare variants (or aggregate burden scores) warrant clinical dose modification.
PMC10786722.title: Integrating rare genetic variants into DPYD pharmacogenetic testing may help preventing fluoropyrimidine-induced toxicity

var_pheno_ann.Notes: Clinically relevant rare DPYD variant (*DPYD*13, rs55886062). Described as a defective allele; significantly associated with low DPD activity measured by [UH2]/[U] plasma ratio (partial DPD deficiency). These variants are known to increase risk of severe fluoropyrimidine toxicity in other studies, but toxicity data were not available in this cohort.
var_pheno_ann.Sentence: c.1679T>G is associated with decreased PK:DPD enzyme activity when treated with 5-fluorouracil or capecitabine in people with Disease:Cancer.
Citations: Dose adjustment based on pretreatment screening for the most clinically relevant *DPYD* defective variants, i.e. c.1679T>G (*DPYD*13*, rs55886062), c.1905+1G>A (*DPYD*2A*, rs3918290) and c.2846A>T (p.Asp949Val or rs67376798), has been shown to improve the safety of chemotherapy regimens based on fluorouracil [29].
As expected, our data showed a significant association between each of these genetic variants and low DPD activity (Fig. [1](#Fig1)).
Of particular interest, our results also showed the importance of considering rare *DPYD* genetic variants to predict the risk of 5-FU toxicity.

var_pheno_ann.Notes: Clinically relevant splice donor variant (*DPYD*2A, rs3918290). Strongly associated with low DPD activity as measured by decreased [UH2]/[U] plasma ratio indicating partial DPD deficiency. Known in the literature to predispose to fluoropyrimidine toxicity, but toxicity was not measured here.

Citations: For this reason, international guidelines now recommend pre-emptive *DPYD* genotyping for several clinically relevant defective variants: i.e., c.1905+1G>A (*DPYD*2A*), c.1679T>G (*DPYD*13*), c.2846A>T, and Haplotype B3 (c.1236G>A or c.1129–5923C>G) as well as genotype-guided prescribing recommendations [[17](#CR17), [18](#CR18)].

Dose adjustment based on pretreatment screening for the most clinically relevant *DPYD* defective variants, i.e. c.1679T>G (*DPYD*13*, rs55886062), c.1905+1G>A (*DPYD*2A*, rs3918290) and c.2846A>T (p.Asp949Val or rs67376798), has been shown to improve the safety of chemotherapy regimens based on fluorouracil [[29](#CR29)].

Specifically, our results confirmed the strong impact of the three clinically rare variants. Additionally, although a significant association between DPD activity and three common known variants including Haplotype B3 was also shown in our large series of patients, their modest effect on DPD activity raises the question of their clinical relevance.

var_pheno_ann.Notes: Clinically relevant missense variant p.Asp949Val (rs67376798). Significantly associated with low DPD activity in this cohort. International guidelines recommend dose reduction of fluoropyrimidines for carriers due to increased toxicity risk in other studies.
var_pheno_ann.Sentence: c.2846A>T is associated with decreased PK:DPD enzyme activity when treated with 5-fluorouracil or capecitabine in people with Disease:Cancer.
Citations: Dose adjustment based on pretreatment screening for the most clinically relevant *DPYD* defective variants, i.e. c.1679T>G (*DPYD*13*, rs55886062), c.1905+1G>A (*DPYD*2A*, rs3918290) and c.2846A>T (p.Asp949Val or rs67376798), has been shown to improve the safety of chemotherapy regimens based on fluorouracil [[29](#CR29)].
As expected, our data showed a significant association between each of these genetic variants and low DPD activity (Fig. [1](#Fig1)).

Indeed, according to PharmGKB, more than 20 loss-of-function *DPYD* variants have been reported to alter DPD enzymatic activity, and consequently patients harboring such variants are exposed to an increased risk of severe toxicity when receiving standard dose of fluoropyrimidine. For this reason, international guidelines now recommend pre-emptive *DPYD* genotyping for several clinically relevant defective variants: i.e., c.1905+1G>A (*DPYD*2A*), c.1679T>G (*DPYD*13*), c.2846A>T, and Haplotype B3 (c.1236G>A or c.1129–5923C>G) as well as genotype-guided prescribing recommendations [[17](#CR17), [18](#CR18)].

var_pheno_ann.Notes: Common synonymous variant rs56038477 (hapB3). Significantly associated with low DPD activity (partial DPD deficiency) in this cohort, but with a modest effect compared to the major defective variants. Included in risk haplotype B3 that has been linked to fluoropyrimidine toxicity in other reports.
var_pheno_ann.Sentence: c.1236G>A is associated with decreased PK:DPD enzyme activity when treated with 5-fluorouracil or capecitabine in people with Disease:Cancer.
Citations: “As expected, our data showed a significant association between each of these genetic variants and low DPD activity (Fig. [1](#Fig1)).”

“The association between common *DPYD* genetic variants (MAF ≥ 1%) and DPD activity is summarized in Fig. [2](#Fig2). Among the seven genetic variants identified, three variants (c.1236G>A or rs56038477 p.Glu412Glu ; c.496A>G or rs2297595 p.Met166Val; *DPYD*6 *c.2194G>A or rs1801160 p.Val732Ile) were significantly more frequent in the group of patients exhibiting partial DPD deficiency. Consistent with previous reports, the c.1236G>A (rs56038477) which is included in the risk haplotype B3 was significantly associated with low DPD activity [[30](#CR30), [31](#CR31)]. Nevertheless, compared to the most clinically relevant *DPYD* defective variants, the association of these three variants with DPD activity was rather modest (Fig. [2](#Fig2)).”

“Specifically, our results confirmed the strong impact of the three clinically rare variants. Additionally, although a significant association between DPD activity and three common known variants including Haplotype B3 was also shown in our large series of patients, their modest effect on DPD activity raises the question of their clinical relevance.”

var_drug_ann.Notes: Simvastatin users (n=916). Using statin switching as intolerance: SLCO1B1 c.521C/C vs T/T HR 1.88 (95% CI 1.08–3.25), P=0.025. Simvastatin dose ≥40 mg also associated with switching vs 10 mg (HR 1.48, 95% CI 1.03–2.12, P=0.035).
var_drug_ann.Sentence: Genotype c.521C/C is associated with increased risk of statin switching as a marker of intolerance to simvastatin in patients with hypercholesterolemia as compared to genotype c.521T/T.
var_drug_ann.PD/PK terms: risk of statin switching as a marker of intolerance to
Citations: We confirmed the association of SLCO1B1 c.521C/C genotype with simvastatin intolerance both by using phenotype of switching initial statin to another as a marker of statin intolerance [hazard ratio (HR) 1.88, 95% confidence interval (CI) 1.08–3.25, P = 0.025] and statin switching along with creatine kinase measurement (HR 5.44, 95% CI 1.49–19.9, P = 0.011).

Of the total 916 simvastatin users, 232 were classified as statin switchers and of those, 22 had a temporally qualifying CK measurement (statin switchers with CK measurement; Fig. [1](#F1)). In the Cox proportional hazards model accounting for the statin dose, SLCO1B1 c.521C/C genotype was associated with an increased risk of simvastatin intolerance when compared to homozygous reference T/T genotype using both statin switcher [hazard ratio (HR) 1.88, 95% confidence interval (CI) 1.08–3.25, P = 0.025] and statin switcher with CK measurement (HR 5.44, 95% CI 1.49–19.9, P = 0.011) phenotypes (Table [2](#T2)). Simvastatin dose of 40 mg or higher was also associated with the statin switcher phenotype when compared to 10 mg dose (HR 1.48, 95% 1.03–2.12, P = 0.035).
In conclusion, SLCO1B1 c.521T>C genotype was associated with increased switching of simvastatin and pravastatin to other statins in an epidemiological biobank study.

var_drug_ann.Notes: Simvastatin users (n=916). Using statin switching plus temporally qualifying CK measurement as intolerance: SLCO1B1 c.521C/C vs T/T HR 5.44 (95% CI 1.49–19.9), P=0.011.
var_drug_ann.Sentence: Genotype c.521C/C is associated with increased risk of statin switching with temporally associated CK measurement as a marker of intolerance to simvastatin in patients with hypercholesterolemia as compared to genotype c.521T/T.
var_drug_ann.PD/PK terms: risk of statin switching with temporally associated CK measurement as a marker of intolerance to
Citations: Of the total 916 simvastatin users, 232 were classified as statin switchers and of those, 22 had a temporally qualifying CK measurement (statin switchers with CK measurement; Fig. [1](#F1)). In the Cox proportional hazards model accounting for the statin dose, *SLCO1B1* c.521C/C genotype was associated with an increased risk of simvastatin intolerance when compared to homozygous reference T/T genotype using both statin switcher [hazard ratio (HR) 1.88, 95% confidence interval (CI) 1.08–3.25, *P* = 0.025] and statin switcher with CK measurement (HR 5.44, 95% CI 1.49–19.9, *P* = 0.011) phenotypes (Table [2](#T2)).

In a large observational cohort of statin initiators, we replicated the well-characterized association of *SLCO1B1* c.521T>C with simvastatin intolerance. The effect was consistent in both of our intolerance phenotypes, the first based on statin switching only and the second based on statin switching and temporally associated CK measurement.

Citations: Atorvastatin had median follow-up time of 556.5 days. There were 780 atorvastatin users. We observed no statistically significant increase in statin intolerance risk for atorvastatin, fluvastatin or rosuvastatin with the studied genotypes. For fluvastatin, there was a trend towards increased risk of statin intolerance with a point estimate of HR at 1.88 in carriers of 2–4 risk alleles, but perhaps due to low sample size, the finding was not statistically significant.

Citations: The sample sizes for fluvastatin and pravastatin were relatively small, but *SLCO1B1* c.521T>C carriers had an increased risk of pravastatin intolerance defined by statin switching when compared to homozygous reference T/T genotype (HR 2.11, 95% CI 1.01–4.39, *P* = 0.047).

Pravastatin had a total of 92 users of which 29 were categorized as statin switchers. *SLCO1B1* c.521T/C or C/C genotype was associated with an increased risk of pravastatin switching when compared to homozygous reference T/T genotype (HR 2.11, 95% CI 1.01–4.39, *P* = 0.047; Table [6](#T6)).

In addition to simvastatin, we observed that heterozygous or homozygous *SLCO1B1* c.521T>C carriers had a higher risk of pravastatin intolerance based on statin switching phenotype when compared to reference allele homozygotes.

PMC10399933.summary:
Objective
To evaluate how common pharmacokinetic variants in SLCO1B1, ABCG2 and CYP2C9 affect real‑world statin intolerance, using nationwide prescription and laboratory data linked to biobank genotypes, and to test whether a register‑based “statin switch” phenotype is a useful proxy for intolerance.

Study design and population
- Register-based cohort from Helsinki Biobank linked to Finnish national prescription and clinical chemistry registries.
- 2,042 incident statin users with consent and DNA (out of 2,242 identified; exclusions mainly for missing genotypes, combination products, and a reimbursement-policy–driven switching period).
- Index statins: simvastatin (n=916), atorvastatin (n=780), rosuvastatin (n=184), fluvastatin (n=70), pravastatin (n=92).

Genetics
- SLCO1B1 rs4149056 (c.521T>C; Val174Ala).
- ABCG2 rs2231142 (c.421C>A; Gln141Lys).
- CYP2C9 rs1799853 (*2), rs1057910 (*3); used to classify CYP2C9 normal, intermediate, poor metabolizers.
- Genotype frequencies in Hardy–Weinberg equilibrium and similar to Finnish reference data.

Phenotyping of statin intolerance
Two operational phenotypes, defined per index statin:
1) Primary: “statin switch” – change from index statin to a different statin (ATC code change; brand changes ignored). Event date = last purchase of index statin.
2) Secondary: “statin switch + CK” – statin switch plus any creatine kinase (CK) measurement from 30 days before to 90 days after the switch (value not required to be elevated), intended to enrich for suspected myopathy.
- Follow-up from first index statin purchase until 365 days without any statin purchase, death, or 31 Dec 2016.
- Cox proportional hazards models adjusted for daily statin dose (categorical). Genotypes modeled additively; dose categories merged if <10 individuals.

Key results by statin

Simvastatin (n=916; median follow-up 532 days)
- Intolerance events: 232 statin switchers; 22 switchers with qualifying CK measurement.
- SLCO1B1 c.521C/C vs T/T:
  - Statin switch: HR 1.88 (95% CI 1.08–3.25; P=0.025).
  - Statin switch + CK: HR 5.44 (95% CI 1.49–19.9; P=0.011).
- Simvastatin dose ≥40 mg vs 10 mg increased switch risk: HR 1.48 (95% CI 1.03–2.12; P=0.035).
- Heterozygotes (T/C) showed no clear increase with the primary switch phenotype.
- This robustly replicates the established association of SLCO1B1*5 (521C) with simvastatin intolerance in real-world data and validates the switch-based phenotype.

Atorvastatin (n=780; median follow-up 556.5 days)
- Intolerance events: 128 switchers; 18 switchers + CK.
- No statistically significant associations for:
  - SLCO1B1 c.521T>C (including C/C) with either phenotype.
  - ABCG2 c.421C>A.
  - Combined “risk allele count” (SLCO1B1 + ABCG2).
  - Atorvastatin dose.
- Point estimates for SLCO1B1 C‑allele carriers in the switch + CK phenotype were in the same direction and magnitude as prior reports, but underpowered to reach significance, likely because most patients were on low–moderate doses (10–20 mg, few at 80 mg).

Rosuvastatin (n=184; median follow-up 92.5 days)
- Intolerance events: 32 switchers; CK-based phenotype not analyzed (too few events).
- Dose: 10 mg vs 5 mg associated with increased switching (HR 3.55; 95% CI 1.07–11.8; P=0.038), consistent with dose-dependent intolerance.
- No significant association with:
  - SLCO1B1 c.521T>C.
  - ABCG2 c.421C>A.
  - Combined risk allele count.
- Short follow-up and small sample limited power; findings are consistent with previous rosuvastatin trial data that did not show SLCO1B1–myalgia association.

Fluvastatin (n=70)
- Intolerance events: 31 switchers.
- No statistically significant associations for SLCO1B1, ABCG2, CYP2C9, or combined risk alleles.
- Some non-significant trends:
  - ABCG2 variant and CYP2C9 reduced function and higher combined risk allele count (2–4 alleles) showed HRs >1 (up to ~1.9) but with wide CIs crossing 1, suggesting possible effect consistent with prior transplant data but underpowered here.

Pravastatin (n=92; median follow-up >2 years)
- Intolerance events: 29 switchers.
- SLCO1B1 c.521T/C or C/C vs T/T:
  - Statin switch: HR 2.11 (95% CI 1.01–4.39; P=0.047).
- Doses were 20–40 mg (40 mg is the European maximum).
- No CK-based phenotype analyzed for pravastatin (too few events).
- This is notable because prior pravastatin safety data (short 16-week trial) did not show such an association; longer follow-up here may better capture late-onset intolerance.

ABCG2 and CYP2C9 overall
- ABCG2 c.421C>A:
  - No clear association with intolerance to atorvastatin, rosuvastatin, simvastatin, fluvastatin, or pravastatin in this cohort.
  - Pharmacokinetic effects seen in prior work did not translate into statistically robust clinical intolerance signals, likely due to limited power.
- CYP2C9 (*2, *3):
  - For fluvastatin, intermediate/poor metabolizers (vs normal) showed a non‑significant HR 1.36 for switching; not definitive.
  - No strong signals of genotype–intolerance association in this dataset.

Methodological and conceptual points
- Phenotype choice: The authors intentionally favored “switching” (rather than discontinuation or dose reduction) as a marker of intolerance, based on preliminary analyses showing better agreement with SLCO1B1–simvastatin associations and to minimize non–intolerance reasons for changes.
- The secondary “switch + CK” phenotype enriched for suspected muscle toxicity (CK measured around the time of switch), capturing both CK-elevated myopathy and myalgias that prompt CK testing even if results are normal.
- Administrative confounding: policy-driven switches from atorvastatin/rosuvastatin around 2006–2007 (due to reimbursement rules) were excluded to avoid bias.
- Limitations:
  - Epidemiologic, retrospective design; cannot prove causality.
  - No direct clinical symptom data or CK values; only timing of CK testing.
  - Small numbers for rosuvastatin, fluvastatin, pravastatin limit precision.
  - Single-country, mainly Finnish, so genotype frequencies and practice patterns may differ elsewhere.

Clinical implications for pharmacogenomics
1) Simvastatin
   - Findings strongly reinforce current CPIC recommendations: SLCO1B1 c.521C/C substantially increases real-world simvastatin intolerance, especially at higher doses.
   - In practice, SLCO1B1 poor-function genotypes should prompt use of a lower-risk statin (e.g., pravastatin, rosuvastatin) or lower simvastatin doses with careful monitoring.

2) Pravastatin
   - SLCO1B1 c.521T>C also increases risk of pravastatin switching (HR ~2.1), suggesting that even “hydrophilic, non–CYP‑metabolized” pravastatin is not completely exempt from OATP1B1-related intolerance.
   - Supports the inclusion of pravastatin in SLCO1B1-based statin choice algorithms, especially at 20–40 mg doses.

3) Atorvastatin, Rosuvastatin, Fluvastatin
   - No statistically significant pharmacogenetic signals in this single cohort, but point estimates are directionally compatible with prior evidence for atorvastatin and fluvastatin.
   - Data are valuable for meta-analyses and guideline refinement; current CPIC recommendations (cautious dosing or alternative statin in high SLCO1B1/ABCG2 risk genotypes, particularly at high doses) remain biologically plausible even if not conclusively supported here.

4) Phenotyping strategy for real-world PGx
   - The study demonstrates that combining prescription data (switches) with laboratory data (CK testing) is a feasible way to create scalable, registry-based pharmacogenomic phenotypes in the absence of structured clinical myopathy documentation.

Overall conclusion
- SLCO1B1 c.521T>C is clearly associated with increased real-world switching from simvastatin and pravastatin to other statins, supporting its role as a key determinant of statin intolerance beyond simvastatin alone.
- No definitive additional associations were demonstrated for ABCG2 or CYP2C9 variants, or for atorvastatin, rosuvastatin, or fluvastatin intolerance, largely due to power and dose limitations.
- The register-based “switch” and “switch + CK” phenotypes appear valid and scalable for future large pharmacogenomic studies and can inform ongoing refinement of statin PGx prescribing guidelines.
PMC10399933.title: Real-world pharmacogenetics of statin intolerance: effects of SLCO1B1, ABCG2, and CYP2C9 variants

var_pheno_ann.Notes: SLCO1B1 c.521C/C genotype was associated with increased risk of simvastatin intolerance defined as statin switching (HR 1.88, 95% CI 1.08–3.25, P=0.025) compared with c.521T/T.
var_pheno_ann.Sentence: c.521C/C is associated with increased risk of Statin intolerance (switch to another statin) when treated with simvastatin in people with Hypercholesterolemia.
var_pheno_ann.Phenotype: Side Effect:Statin intolerance (switch to another statin)
Citations: We confirmed the association of SLCO1B1 c.521C/C genotype with simvastatin intolerance both by using phenotype of switching initial statin to another as a marker of statin intolerance [hazard ratio (HR) 1.88, 95% confidence interval (CI) 1.08–3.25, P = 0.025] and statin switching along with creatine kinase measurement (HR 5.44, 95% CI 1.49–19.9, P = 0.011).

In the Cox proportional hazards model accounting for the statin dose, SLCO1B1 c.521C/C genotype was associated with an increased risk of simvastatin intolerance when compared to homozygous reference T/T genotype using both statin switcher [hazard ratio (HR) 1.88, 95% confidence interval (CI) 1.08–3.25, P = 0.025] and statin switcher with CK measurement (HR 5.44, 95% CI 1.49–19.9, P = 0.011) phenotypes (Table [2](#T2)).
In conclusion, SLCO1B1 c.521T>C genotype was associated with increased switching of simvastatin and pravastatin to other statins in an epidemiological biobank study.

var_pheno_ann.Notes: SLCO1B1 c.521C/C genotype was associated with increased risk of simvastatin intolerance defined as statin switching plus temporally related CK measurement (HR 5.44, 95% CI 1.49–19.9, P=0.011) compared with c.521T/T.
var_pheno_ann.Sentence: c.521C/C is associated with increased risk of Statin intolerance (switch plus CK measurement) when treated with simvastatin in people with Hypercholesterolemia.
var_pheno_ann.Phenotype: Side Effect:Statin intolerance (switch plus CK measurement)
Citations: We confirmed the association of SLCO1B1 c.521C/C genotype with simvastatin intolerance both by using phenotype of switching initial statin to another as a marker of statin intolerance [hazard ratio (HR) 1.88, 95% confidence interval (CI) 1.08–3.25, P = 0.025] and statin switching along with creatine kinase measurement (HR 5.44, 95% CI 1.49–19.9, P = 0.011).

In the Cox proportional hazards model accounting for the statin dose, SLCO1B1 c.521C/C genotype was associated with an increased risk of simvastatin intolerance when compared to homozygous reference T/T genotype using both statin switcher [hazard ratio (HR) 1.88, 95% confidence interval (CI) 1.08–3.25, P = 0.025] and statin switcher with CK measurement (HR 5.44, 95% CI 1.49–19.9, P = 0.011) phenotypes (Table [2](#T2)).
In conclusion, SLCO1B1 c.521T>C genotype was associated with increased switching of simvastatin and pravastatin to other statins in an epidemiological biobank study.

var_pheno_ann.Notes: SLCO1B1 c.521T/C or C/C genotype was associated with increased risk of pravastatin intolerance defined by statin switching when compared to c.521T/T (HR 2.11, 95% CI 1.01–4.39, P=0.047).
var_pheno_ann.Sentence: c.521T/C or C/C is associated with increased risk of Statin intolerance (switch to another statin) when treated with pravastatin in people with Hypercholesterolemia.
var_pheno_ann.Phenotype: Side Effect:Statin intolerance (switch to another statin)
Citations: “The sample sizes for fluvastatin and pravastatin were relatively small, but SLCO1B1 c.521T>C carriers had an increased risk of pravastatin intolerance defined by statin switching when compared to homozygous reference T/T genotype (HR 2.11, 95% CI 1.01–4.39, P = 0.047).”

“Pravastatin had a total of 92 users of which 29 were categorized as statin switchers. SLCO1B1 c.521T/C or C/C genotype was associated with an increased risk of pravastatin switching when compared to homozygous reference T/T genotype (HR 2.11, 95% CI 1.01–4.39, P = 0.047; Table [6]).”

“In addition to simvastatin, we observed that heterozygous or homozygous SLCO1B1 c.521T>C carriers had a higher risk of pravastatin intolerance based on statin switching phenotype when compared to reference allele homozygotes.”

var_drug_ann.Notes: Patients with VKORC1 −1639 AA and GA genotypes required 49.7% and 27.7% lower stable weekly warfarin doses than GG (p<0.001). In multivariate regression, GA and AA genotypes were associated with warfarin dose reductions of 9.7 mg and 18.1 mg/week versus GG (p<0.001), and VKORC1 explained 26.2% of dose variance.
var_drug_ann.Sentence: Genotypes AA and GA is associated with decreased stable weekly dose requirements of warfarin in patients with thromboembolic diseases as compared to genotype GG.
var_drug_ann.Population Phenotypes or diseases: Disease:atrial fibrillation, Disease:heart valve replacement, Disease:deep vein thrombosis, Disease:pulmonary embolism, Disease:chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension
Citations: Patients with AA and GA genotypes of VKORC1 − 1639G > A required 49.7% and 27.7% significantly lower averages of SWDS of warfarin as compared with those with wild-type GG genotype (p < 0.001).
The warfarin SWDs were decreased by 9.7 mg and 18.1 mg in the patients with GA and AA genotypes of VKORC1 − 1639G > A as compared with those with wild-type GG genotype (p < 0.001) (Table [3](#Tab3)).

In this study, it confirmed the previous findings that VKORC1 − 1639G > A and CYP2C9*3 were the major genetic determinants of warfarin dose requirements, with CYP4F2 having a smaller effect [[3](#CR3), [23](#CR23), [24](#CR24)].

var_drug_ann.Notes: Mean stable weekly doses: *1/*1 22.6±9.2 mg, *1/*3 14.9±5.3 mg, *3/*3 8.0 mg; overall genotype effect p=0.006. In multivariate regression, *1/*3 and *3/*3 genotypes were associated with 7.9 mg and 25.9 mg/week lower warfarin doses versus *1/*1 (p<0.001), explaining ~6% of dose variance.
var_drug_ann.Sentence: Genotypes *1/*3 and *3/*3 is associated with decreased stable weekly dose requirements of warfarin in patients with thromboembolic diseases as compared to genotype *1/*1.
var_drug_ann.Population Phenotypes or diseases: Disease:atrial fibrillation, Disease:heart valve replacement, Disease:deep vein thrombosis, Disease:pulmonary embolism, Disease:chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension
Citations: “The averages of warfarin SWDs were 64.6% and 34.1% lower in CYP2C9 *3/*3 and *1/*3 patients than in *1/*1 patients (*p* = 0.006).”

“Similarly, the warfarin SWDs were decreased by 7.9 mg and 25.9 mg in the patients with CYP2C9 *1/*3 and CYP2C9 *3/*3 genotypes as compared with those with wild-type *1/*1 genotype (*p* < 0.001) (Table [3](#Tab3)).”

var_drug_ann.Notes: Univariate analysis: mean stable weekly doses CC 22.2±10.0 mg, CT 21.8±7.4 mg, TT 25.8±8.4 mg; overall p=0.172, indicating no significant difference among genotypes in stable weekly warfarin dose.
var_drug_ann.Sentence: Genotypes CT and TT is not associated with stable weekly dose requirements of warfarin in patients with thromboembolic diseases as compared to genotype CC.
var_drug_ann.Population Phenotypes or diseases: Disease:atrial fibrillation, Disease:heart valve replacement, Disease:deep vein thrombosis, Disease:pulmonary embolism, Disease:chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension
Citations: “The dosage requirement differences, however, were not observed in patients with variant genotypes of *CYP4F2* rs2108622 and *UGT1A1* rs887829 (*p* = 0.172 and *p* = 0.921) (Table [2](#Tab2)).”

var_drug_ann.Notes: In multiple linear regression, CYP4F2 rs2108622 TT genotype increased warfarin stable weekly dose by 4.1 mg versus CC (β=4.149, p=0.016) and accounted for 1.2% of dose variability.
var_drug_ann.Sentence: Genotype TT is associated with increased stable weekly dose requirements of warfarin in patients with thromboembolic diseases as compared to genotype CC.
var_drug_ann.Population Phenotypes or diseases: Disease:atrial fibrillation, Disease:heart valve replacement, Disease:deep vein thrombosis, Disease:pulmonary embolism, Disease:chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension
Citations: “A multiple linear regression model using the predictors including *VKORC1* − 1639G > A, *CYP2C9*3*, and *CYP4F2* rs2108622, age, BMI, antiplatelet drug use, amiodarone use, current smoking status explained 51.3% of individual differences in the stable warfarin doses (Table [3](#Tab3)). … In addition, warfarin SWDs were increased by 4.1 mg in the patients with the TT variant genotype of *CYP4F2* rs2108622 as compared with those with the wild-type CC genotype (*p* = 0.016) (Table [3](#Tab3)).”

“According to the *CYP4F2* rs2108622 polymorphism, the results revealed that the variant TT genotype was identified as a significant contributor and accounted for a modest part of warfarin dose variability (1.2%) (Table [3](#Tab3)).”

var_drug_ann.Notes: Mean stable weekly doses by genotype: CC 22.0±9.1 mg, CT 23.0±9.6 mg, TT 22.8±17.3 mg; overall p=0.921, indicating that rs887829 did not significantly contribute to variability in stable warfarin dose.
var_drug_ann.Sentence: Genotypes CT and TT is not associated with stable weekly dose requirements of warfarin in patients with thromboembolic diseases as compared to genotype CC.
var_drug_ann.Population Phenotypes or diseases: Disease:atrial fibrillation, Disease:heart valve replacement, Disease:deep vein thrombosis, Disease:pulmonary embolism, Disease:chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension
Citations: The comparisons of warfarin SWDs among those patients with different genotypes are shown in Table [2](#Tab2). Patients with AA and GA genotypes of *VKORC1* − 1639G > A required 49.7% and 27.7% significantly lower averages of SWDS of warfarin as compared with those with wild-type GG genotype (*p* < 0.001). The averages of warfarin SWDs were 64.6% and 34.1% lower in *CYP2C9 *3/*3* and **1/*3* patients than in **1/*1* patients (*p* = 0.006). **The dosage requirement differences, however, were not observed in patients with variant genotypes of *CYP4F2* rs2108622 and *UGT1A1* rs887829 (*p* = 0.172 and *p* = 0.921) (Table [2](#Tab2)).**

According to the *UGT1A1* rs887829 polymorphism, the present results showed that *UGT1A1* rs887829 did not significantly contribute to the variability of the stable warfarin doses (Table [2](#Tab2)) which was not consistent with the study of Korean patients [[18](#CR18)].

var_fa_ann.Notes: In 250 Thai patients, carriers of VKORC1 −1639G>A variant genotypes required substantially lower stable weekly warfarin doses than GG homozygotes. AA and GA genotypes required 49.7% and 27.7% lower average doses, respectively, compared with GG (p<0.001). In multivariate linear regression, GA and AA genotypes decreased dose by 9.7 mg and 18.1 mg per week, respectively, versus GG (p<0.001). VKORC1 −1639G>A genotypes together explained 26.2% of warfarin dose variance.
var_fa_ann.Sentence: rs9923231 is associated with decreased stable weekly dose requirements of warfarin in Thai patients as compared to the VKORC1 −1639 GG genotype.
var_fa_ann.Assay type: clinical dose–response association
Citations: The patients with variant genotypes of VKORC1 − 1639G > A required significantly lower warfarin stable weekly doses (SWDs) than those with wild-type genotype (*p* < 0.001).
Patients with AA and GA genotypes of VKORC1 − 1639G > A required 49.7% and 27.7% significantly lower averages of SWDS of warfarin as compared with those with wild-type GG genotype (*p* < 0.001).

The warfarin SWDs were decreased by 9.7 mg and 18.1 mg in the patients with GA and AA genotypes of VKORC1 − 1639G > A as compared with those with wild-type GG genotype (*p* < 0.001) (Table [3](#Tab3)).

var_fa_ann.Notes: CYP2C9*3 (1075A>C; rs1057910) variant alleles were associated with lower stable weekly doses of warfarin. Mean doses were 22.6±9.2 mg for *1/*1, 14.9±5.3 mg for *1/*3, and 8.0 mg for *3/*3, with overall p=0.006. In multivariate regression, *1/*3 and *3/*3 genotypes decreased dose by 7.9 mg and 25.9 mg per week, respectively, compared with *1/*1 (p<0.001). CYP2C9*3 genotypes together explained about 6% of dose variance.
var_fa_ann.Sentence: rs1057910 is associated with decreased stable weekly dose requirements of warfarin in Thai patients as compared to the CYP2C9 *1/*1 genotype.
var_fa_ann.Assay type: clinical dose–response association
Citations: “Similarly, the patients with CYP2C9*3 variant allele required significantly lower warfarin SWDs than those with homozygous wild-type (p = 0.006).”
“The averages of warfarin SWDs were 64.6% and 34.1% lower in CYP2C9 *3/*3 and *1/*3 patients than in *1/*1 patients (p = 0.006).”

“Similarly, the warfarin SWDs were decreased by 7.9 mg and 25.9 mg in the patients with CYP2C9 *1/*3 and CYP2C9 *3/*3 genotypes as compared with those with wild-type *1/*1 genotype (p < 0.001) (Table [3]).”

var_fa_ann.Notes: In univariate analysis, CYP4F2 rs2108622 genotypes (CC, CT, TT) showed no statistically significant differences in warfarin stable weekly doses (p=0.172). However, in multiple linear regression including clinical and genetic covariates, the TT genotype was associated with an increase of 4.15 mg/week in stable warfarin dose compared with the CC genotype (p=0.016), accounting for approximately 1.2% of dose variability.
var_fa_ann.Sentence: CYP4F2 rs2108622 TT genotype is associated with increased stable weekly dose requirements of warfarin in Thai patients as compared to the CYP4F2 rs2108622 CC genotype.
var_fa_ann.Assay type: clinical dose–response association
Citations: “In addition, warfarin SWDs were increased by 4.1 mg in the patients with the TT variant genotype of *CYP4F2* rs2108622 as compared with those with the wild-type CC genotype (*p* = 0.016) (Table [3](#Tab3)).”

“For the *CYP4F2* rs2108622 polymorphism, the results revealed that the variant TT genotype was identified as a significant contributor and accounted for a modest part of warfarin dose variability (1.2%) (Table [3](#Tab3)).”

“In contrast, there were no significant differences in the SWDs between the patients who carried variant alleles of *CYP4F2* rs2108622 and *UGT1A1* rs887829 as compared to wild-type allele carriers. Multivariate analysis, however, showed that *CYP4F2* rs2108622 TT genotype accounted for a modest part of warfarin dose variability (1.2%).”

var_fa_ann.Notes: UGT1A1 rs887829 genotypes (CC, CT, TT) were not associated with differences in stable weekly warfarin doses in this Thai cohort. Mean doses were 22.0±9.1 mg for CC, 23.0±9.6 mg for CT, and 22.8±17.3 mg for TT, with p=0.921, indicating no significant contribution of this polymorphism to warfarin dose variability.
var_fa_ann.Sentence: UGT1A1 rs887829 is not associated with altered stable weekly dose requirements of warfarin in Thai patients as compared to the UGT1A1 rs887829 CC genotype.
var_fa_ann.Assay type: clinical dose–response association
Citations: In contrast, there were no significant differences in the SWDs between the patients who carried variant alleles of *CYP4F2* rs2108622 and *UGT1A1* rs887829 as compared to wild-type allele carriers.

For the *CYP4F2* rs2108622 polymorphism, the results revealed that the variant TT genotype was identified as a significant contributor and accounted for a modest part of warfarin dose variability (1.2%) (Table [3](#Tab3)). Similarly, the previous studies in Asians and Caucasians reported that the predictive contribution of *CYP4F2* rs2108622 varied from 1.4–4.0% [[3](#CR3), [23](#CR23), [24](#CR24)]. According to the *UGT1A1* rs887829 polymorphism, the present results showed that *UGT1A1* rs887829 did not significantly contribute to the variability of the stable warfarin doses (Table [2](#Tab2)) which was not consistent with the study of Korean patients [[18](#CR18)].

PMC5508045.summary:
Study design and population:
- Retrospective pharmacogenomic study in 250 Thai adults on long‑term warfarin with stable weekly doses (SWDs) and INRs 2.0–3.0.
- Collected demographic/clinical data (age, BMI, indication, co-medications, smoking) and genotyped four SNPs: VKORC1 −1639G>A, CYP2C9*3 (rs1057910), CYP4F2 rs2108622, and UGT1A1 rs887829.

Key findings – genetic factors:
- VKORC1 −1639G>A was the strongest determinant of dose:
  - AA and GA genotypes required ~50% and ~28% lower SWDs than GG.
  - In multivariable modeling, VKORC1 explained 26.2% of dose variance (22.5% AA, 3.7% GA).
- CYP2C9*3 had a moderate effect:
  - *1/*3 and *3/*3 genotypes required ~34% and ~65% lower SWDs than *1/*1.
  - Accounted for ~6.0% of variability (3.3% *3/*3, 2.7% *1/*3), consistent with its lower allele frequency in Asians.
- CYP4F2 rs2108622 had a modest, dose‑increasing effect:
  - TT genotype associated with +4.1 mg/week vs CC in multivariable analysis.
  - Contributed 1.2% to dose variance.
- UGT1A1 rs887829 had no detectable impact on warfarin dose in this Thai cohort, despite prior positive reports in Koreans and Brazilians.

Key findings – non‑genetic factors:
- Age: strong negative relationship with dose (−0.25 mg/week per year; r = −0.33). Patients ≥60 years required significantly lower doses than those 20–39.
- BMI: positive relationship with dose (+0.345 mg/week per BMI unit). Class I–II obesity required ~25% higher doses than normal BMI.
- Co‑medications:
  - Amiodarone: −7.2 mg/week (3.0% of variance), consistent with inhibition of warfarin metabolism.
  - Antiplatelet drugs (clopidogrel, prasugrel, ticagrelor): −3.4 mg/week (1.0% of variance).
- Smoking: Current smokers required ~4.0 mg/week higher doses (0.8% of variance), likely via CYP1A2 induction and increased warfarin clearance.
- Sex, height, and UGT1A1 genotype were not significant predictors.

Explained variability and model performance:
- Stepwise multiple linear regression including VKORC1, CYP2C9*3, CYP4F2 rs2108622, age, BMI, amiodarone use, antiplatelet use, and current smoking explained 51.3% of variability in stable warfarin dose.
- Approximate contributions to R²:
  - VKORC1 −1639G>A: 26.2%
  - Age: 10.8%
  - CYP2C9*3: 6.0%
  - Amiodarone: 3.0%
  - BMI: 2.3%
  - CYP4F2 rs2108622 (TT): 1.2%
  - Antiplatelets: 1.0%
  - Smoking: 0.8%

Clinical and pharmacogenomic implications:
- In Thai patients, VKORC1 −1639G>A and CYP2C9*3 are the primary pharmacogenomic drivers of warfarin dose, with CYP4F2 rs2108622 exerting a smaller, dose‑increasing effect.
- UGT1A1 rs887829 does not appear to be clinically useful for warfarin dose prediction in this population, despite mechanistic plausibility and prior positive studies in other ethnic groups.
- Clinical factors—especially age, BMI, and co‑treatment with amiodarone or antiplatelet agents, plus smoking status—meaningfully modify warfarin requirements and should be considered alongside genotype.
- A combined algorithm incorporating VKORC1, CYP2C9, CYP4F2 plus age, BMI, and key co‑medications can explain about half of warfarin dose variability in Thais; diet and other unmeasured factors likely account for much of the remainder.
- Findings support population‑specific warfarin pharmacogenetic dosing approaches in Southeast Asians, emphasizing VKORC1/CYP2C9/CYP4F2 together with age and BMI, while not prioritizing UGT1A1 genotyping for warfarin.

Limitations noted by authors:
- Retrospective design; vitamin K intake and some other confounders were not controlled.
- Relatively small numbers for some genotypes (e.g., CYP2C9*3/*3, UGT1A1 TT), limiting precision of those estimates.
- Results may not generalize beyond Thai patients with similar clinical characteristics.

Overall conclusion:
- In Thai patients, stable warfarin dose is jointly determined by VKORC1 −1639G>A, CYP2C9*3, CYP4F2 rs2108622 and by age, BMI, amiodarone, antiplatelet use, and smoking status, which together account for 51.3% of inter‑individual dose variability. UGT1A1 rs887829 is not a meaningful predictor in this population.

These data support using a warfarin dosing algorithm tailored to Thais that includes VKORC1, CYP2C9, CYP4F2 and key clinical covariates for more accurate initial and maintenance dose prediction, with a call for prospective studies to test clinical utility.
PMC5508045.title: The impact of non-genetic and genetic factors on a stable warfarin dose in Thai patients

var_pheno_ann.Notes: Patients with VKORC1 −1639 AA genotype required 49.7% lower and GA genotype 27.7% lower mean stable weekly warfarin doses than GG genotype (p<0.001). Multiple regression: AA and GA genotypes decreased dose by 18.1 mg and 9.7 mg vs GG; VKORC1 −1639G>A accounted for 26.2% of dose variance.
var_pheno_ann.Sentence: rs9923231 Is Associated with decreased likelihood of Other:Dose requirement when treated with warfarin in people with Disease:Thromboembolic diseases.
Citations: Patients with AA and GA genotypes of *VKORC1* − 1639G > A required 49.7% and 27.7% significantly lower averages of SWDS of warfarin as compared with those with wild-type GG genotype (*p* < 0.001).

The warfarin SWDs were decreased by 9.7 mg and 18.1 mg in the patients with GA and AA genotypes of *VKORC1* − 1639G > A as compared with those with wild-type GG genotype (*p* < 0.001) (Table [3](#Tab3)).

In this study, it confirmed the previous findings that *VKORC1* − 1639G > A and *CYP2C9*3* were the major genetic determinants of warfarin dose requirements, with CYP4F2 having a smaller effect [[3](#CR3), [23](#CR23), [24](#CR24)].

var_pheno_ann.Notes: Mean warfarin stable weekly dose (SWD) was 22.6±9.2 mg for CYP2C9*1/*1, 14.9±5.3 mg for *1/*3, and 8.0 mg for *3/*3 (p=0.006). SWDs were 34.1% and 64.6% lower in *1/*3 and *3/*3 than *1/*1. Multiple regression: *1/*3 and *3/*3 reduced dose by 7.9 mg and 25.9 mg vs *1/*1; CYP2C9*3 explained about 6.0% of dose variance.
var_pheno_ann.Sentence: CYP2C9*3 Is Associated with decreased likelihood of Other:Dose requirement when treated with warfarin in people with Disease:Thromboembolic diseases.
Citations: "Similarly, the patients with CYP2C9*3 variant allele required significantly lower warfarin SWDs than those with homozygous wild-type (p = 0.006)."
"The averages of warfarin SWDs were 64.6% and 34.1% lower in CYP2C9 *3/*3 and *1/*3 patients than in *1/*1 patients (p = 0.006)."

"Similarly, the warfarin SWDs were decreased by 7.9 mg and 25.9 mg in the patients with CYP2C9 *1/*3 and CYP2C9 *3/*3 genotypes as compared with those with wild-type *1/*1 genotype (p < 0.001) (Table [3](#Tab3))."

var_pheno_ann.Notes: Univariate analysis: no significant difference in stable weekly doses among CYP4F2 rs2108622 CC, CT, TT genotypes (p=0.172); mean SWDs: CC 22.2±10.0 mg, CT 21.8±7.4 mg, TT 25.8±8.4 mg. Multivariate model: TT genotype associated with 4.1 mg higher dose vs CC (p=0.016) and contributed 1.2% of dose variability.
var_pheno_ann.Sentence: rs2108622 Is Associated with increased likelihood of Other:Dose requirement when treated with warfarin in people with Disease:Thromboembolic diseases.
Citations: "In contrast, there were no significant differences in the SWDs between the patients who carried variant alleles of *CYP4F2* rs2108622 and *UGT1A1* rs887829 as compared to wild-type allele carriers. Multivariate analysis, however, showed that *CYP4F2* rs2108622 TT genotype accounted for a modest part of warfarin dose variability (1.2%)."
"The dosage requirement differences, however, were not observed in patients with variant genotypes of *CYP4F2* rs2108622 and *UGT1A1* rs887829 (*p* = 0.172 and *p* = 0.921) (Table [2](#Tab2))."

"In addition, warfarin SWDs were increased by 4.1 mg in the patients with the TT variant genotype of *CYP4F2* rs2108622 as compared with those with the wild-type CC genotype (*p* = 0.016) (Table [3](#Tab3))."

var_pheno_ann.Notes: Mean warfarin SWDs for UGT1A1 rs887829 genotypes: CC 22.0±9.1 mg, CT 23.0±9.6 mg, TT 22.8±17.3 mg; p=0.921. Authors conclude UGT1A1 rs887829 did not contribute to dose variability in multivariate analyses.
var_pheno_ann.Sentence: rs887829 Is Not associated with Other:Dose requirement when treated with warfarin in people with Disease:Thromboembolic diseases.
Citations: In contrast, there were no significant differences in the SWDs between the patients who carried variant alleles of CYP4F2 rs2108622 and UGT1A1 rs887829 as compared to wild-type allele carriers. Multivariate analysis, however, showed that CYP4F2 rs2108622 TT genotype accounted for a modest part of warfarin dose variability (1.2%). In contrast, VKORC1 − 1639G > A, CYP2C9*3, CYP4F2 rs2108622 genotypes and non-genetic factors accounted for 51.3% of dose variability.

According to the UGT1A1 rs887829 polymorphism, the present results showed that UGT1A1 rs887829 did not significantly contribute to the variability of the stable warfarin doses (Table [2](#Tab2)) which was not consistent with the study of Korean patients [18].

var_drug_ann.Notes: Among 100 Iraqi RA patients treated with anti-TNF-α (etanercept or infliximab), CARD8 rs2043211 TT genotype was markedly enriched in non-responders (15/34) vs responders (1/66), overall genotype-response association P<0.0001. Dominant model (AA+AT vs TT): responders 65 vs 1; non-responders 19 vs 15; P<0.0001, OR 0.019 (95% CI 0.002–0.157). Recessive model (AA vs AT+TT): responders 5 vs 29; non-responders 32 vs 34; P=0.001, OR 0.183 (95% CI 0.063–0.531). Same genotypic effects apply across both TNF inhibitors; no difference in response between etanercept and infliximab (P=0.120).
var_drug_ann.Sentence: Genotype TT is associated with decreased response to etanercept in patients with rheumatoid arthritis as compared to genotypes AA + AT.

The ANOVA test was performed to determine if the relationship of DAS-28 and SNPs was linked to dominant or recessive models ([Table 8](#tbl8)). Patients with CARD8 (rs2043211) A allele bearing genotypes (wild homozygous and heterozygous genotypes) associated with lower DAS- as compared to those with T allele bearing genotypes (Variant homozygous genotypes and heterozygous genotypes. This assume that CARD8 (rs2043211) variant genotypes are associated with lower response to anti-TNF-α treatments in RA patients.

Thirty-four of 100 RA patients (14 etanercept and 20 infliximab) did not respond to anti-TNF-α therapy, while 66 (38 and 28) did. [Table 4](#tbl4) shows that the difference in treatment response between the two drugs was not statistically significant (P = 0.120).

var_drug_ann.Notes: In the same 100 RA patients (52 etanercept, 48 infliximab), total non-responders were 34 (14 etanercept, 20 infliximab). CARD8 rs2043211 TT genotype was significantly more frequent in non-responders vs responders (15 vs 1 overall), P<0.0001. Dominant and recessive models showed strong associations with non-response as above. No significant difference in response rates between infliximab and etanercept (P=0.120), implying similar direction of genetic effect for both drugs.

A significant difference in the CARD8 (rs2043211) genotypes (P < 0.0001 for TNF-α and IL- 1β) as well as, NLRP3 (rs4612666) genotypes (P < 0.0001 for TNF-α and IL- 1β), [Table 7](#tbl7).

Moreover, NLRP3 (rs4612666), C Allele bearing genotypes (wild homozygous and heterozygous genotypes) are associated with lower DAS-28 as compared with T allele bearing genotypes (Variant homozygous and heterozygous genotypes (P < 0.0001 and 0.003 respectively), this supposing that NLRP3 (rs4612666) variant genotypes are extremely associated with higher disease progression and lower response to anti-TNF-α drugs. … Recessive model of NLRP3 (rs4612666) was associated with higher TNF-α and IL- 1β serum level after 3 months of treatment (P = 0.002 and P < 0.0001 respectively), where T allele bearing genotypes (Variant homozygous and heterozygous) were significantly associated with higher cytokines level.

PMC10275785.summary:
Study question and design:
- Case–control pharmacogenomic study in Iraqi rheumatoid arthritis (RA) patients.
- 100 RA patients on anti‑TNF‑α therapy (etanercept or infliximab) and 100 age/sex-matched apparently healthy controls.
- Investigated whether NLRP3 rs4612666 (C>T) and CARD8 rs2043211 (A>T) polymorphisms influence: (1) RA susceptibility, (2) disease activity, (3) serum TNF‑α and IL‑1β, and (4) clinical response to TNF‑α inhibitors.

Methods (PGx‑relevant):
- Genotyping: SYBR Green-based real‑time PCR allelic discrimination (tri‑plex) for NLRP3 rs4612666 and CARD8 rs2043211.
- Phenotyping/clinical data: DAS‑28, EULAR-based classification into responders vs non‑responders after 3 months of etanercept or infliximab.
- Biomarkers: serum TNF‑α and IL‑1β (sandwich ELISA). 

Key baseline/clinical findings:
- RA patients had significantly higher mean serum TNF‑α (7.84 vs 6.09 pg/mL; P = 0.0005) and IL‑1β (2.18 vs 1.21 pg/mL; P < 0.0001) than controls.
- DAS‑28 correlated positively with TNF‑α (r² = 0.45) and IL‑1β (r² = 0.51), both P < 0.0001.
- 66% of patients were responders and 34% non‑responders after 3 months; etanercept and infliximab had comparable efficacy.
- Non‑responders had much higher cytokine levels (TNF‑α ≈ 13.7 vs 4.8 pg/mL; IL‑1β ≈ 3.36 vs 1.57 pg/mL; both P < 0.0001).

Genetic associations – disease susceptibility:
- No significant difference in genotype or allele frequencies between RA cases and controls for either SNP:
  - CARD8 rs2043211: genotype P = 0.17; allele P = 0.059, MAF patients 0.395 vs controls 0.305.
  - NLRP3 rs4612666: genotype P = 0.08; allele P = 0.879, similar MAF (~0.32 vs 0.31).
- Conclusion: In this Iraqi cohort, CARD8 rs2043211 and NLRP3 rs4612666 are not major susceptibility loci for RA onset.

Genotype–phenotype associations within RA patients:
1) Disease activity (DAS‑28 and EULAR category)
- CARD8 rs2043211:
  - TT (variant homozygote) associated with significantly higher DAS‑28 (mean ≈ 4.65 vs 3.51 for AA; P < 0.0001).
  - Genotype distribution differed across disease activity categories (P = 0.033); TT concentrated in moderate/high disease activity; absent in remission/low activity.
  - Recessive T‑allele model (AA vs AT+TT) associated with higher disease activity (P = 0.029) and higher DAS‑28 (P = 0.003).

- NLRP3 rs4612666:
  - TT associated with higher DAS‑28 (≈ 4.72 vs 3.52 for CC; P < 0.0001).
  - Genotype distribution also differed across activity categories (P = 0.008), with TT and CT enriched in moderate/high activity.
  - Recessive T‑allele model (CC vs CT+TT) associated with higher disease activity (P = 0.002) and worse DAS‑28 (P < 0.0001).

2) Response to anti‑TNF‑α therapy
- Clear pharmacogenomic signal for both loci.

- CARD8 rs2043211:
  - Strong difference in genotype distribution between responders and non‑responders (P < 0.0001).
  - TT genotype heavily enriched among non‑responders; AA strongly enriched among responders.
  - Dominant “T‑carrier” model (AA+AT vs TT) and recessive “T‑carrier” model (AA vs AT+TT) both associated with poor response; ORs indicate T‑allele bearing genotypes predict lower likelihood of response (e.g., for recessive model, OR ~0.18 for response when comparing AA to AT+TT).

- NLRP3 rs4612666:
  - Similarly, genotype distribution differs strongly between responders and non‑responders (P < 0.0001).
  - TT and CT genotypes are over‑represented among non‑responders; CC among responders.
  - Dominant C‑allele model (CC+CT vs TT) associated with better response (P < 0.0001, OR ~0.04–0.13 vs recessive T‑carrier models), while recessive T‑allele model (CC vs CT+TT) associates with non‑response.

3) Cytokine levels by genotype
- CARD8 rs2043211:
  - TNF‑α and IL‑1β levels increase markedly across AA → AT → TT (P < 0.0001 for both cytokines).
  - AA: lowest TNF‑α (~5.6 pg/mL) and IL‑1β (~1.05 pg/mL); TT: highest TNF‑α (~14.3 pg/mL) and IL‑1β (~4.55 pg/mL).
  - Dominant model (AA+AT vs TT): TT associated with substantially higher TNF‑α and IL‑1β (P < 0.0001).
  - Recessive model (AA vs AT+TT): T‑carrier genotypes associated with higher cytokines (P < 0.0001).

- NLRP3 rs4612666:
  - Similarly, CC has lowest TNF‑α/IL‑1β; TT has highest levels; both P < 0.0001.
  - Recessive T‑allele model (CC vs CT+TT) significantly associated with higher TNF‑α (P = 0.002) and IL‑1β (P < 0.0001).
  - Dominant (CC+CT vs TT) model was not significantly associated with cytokine levels (TNF‑α P = 0.764, IL‑1β P = 0.187), suggesting a threshold (recessive-like) effect for rs4612666.

Pharmacogenomic interpretation:
- Neither variant confers strong *risk* for developing RA in this Iraqi population, but both are strong *modifiers* of disease course and biological drug response.
- Functional rationale:
  - CARD8 encodes a negative regulator of caspase‑1 and NF‑κB. The rs2043211 T allele introduces a premature stop codon (p.C10X), generating truncated CARD8 with reduced inhibitory capacity, leading to enhanced NF‑κB signaling and increased IL‑1β and TNF‑α production.
  - NLRP3 is a core inflammasome component. The rs4612666 T allele has been linked in other work to altered intronic enhancer activity and reduced mRNA expression, but overall, this and prior RA studies suggest that NLRP3 variation modulates inflammasome activation and IL‑1β production in vivo.
- Clinical consequence:
  - Patients with CARD8 rs2043211 TT and/or NLRP3 rs4612666 TT genotypes exhibit:
    - Higher systemic TNF‑α and IL‑1β despite TNF‑α blockade.
    - Higher DAS‑28 and predominance of moderate/high disease activity.
    - Significantly lower probability of achieving EULAR-defined response to etanercept or infliximab after 3 months.
- This pattern is consistent with the idea that stronger/upstream inflammasome‑mediated IL‑1β/TNF‑α signaling in these genotypes overwhelms standard anti‑TNF‑α therapy, making them “poor responders.”

Clinical and research implications:
- These data support NLRP3/CARD8 genotyping as candidate pharmacogenomic markers for predicting short‑term anti‑TNF‑α response in RA, at least in this Iraqi cohort.
- Patients carrying CARD8 rs2043211 T allele and/or NLRP3 rs4612666 T allele may:
  - Be at higher risk for persistent high disease activity on infliximab or etanercept.
  - Require closer early monitoring, faster therapy escalation, or alternative biologic strategies (e.g., IL‑6 or IL‑1 pathway targeting, JAK inhibitors).
- However, clinical implementation is premature:
  - Single‑center, modest sample size (n=100 RA).
  - Only two SNPs studied; no correction for multiple testing discussed.
  - Three‑month outcome window; long‑term predictive value is unknown.
  - Findings may be population‑specific (Iraqi, Middle Eastern ancestry).

Limitations acknowledged by authors:
- Small cohort and drop‑outs before 3 months reduce power.
- Female predominance typical for RA but limits sex‑stratified genetic analysis.
- Only two inflammasome‑related SNPs examined; comprehensive NLRP3/CARD8 haplotypes not assessed.
- Results may not generalize beyond the Iraqi population due to ethnic genetic heterogeneity.

Overall conclusion:
- In Iraqi RA patients, NLRP3 rs4612666 and CARD8 rs2043211 do not significantly alter RA susceptibility, but their variant (T) genotypes are strongly associated with:
  - Higher TNF‑α and IL‑1β levels
  - More active disease (higher DAS‑28)
  - Poorer clinical response to infliximab and etanercept at 3 months.
- These SNPs are promising pharmacogenomic markers of anti‑TNF‑α response and disease severity, supporting a central role of the NLRP3–CARD8 inflammasome axis in RA pathobiology and biologic treatment outcomes.
PMC10275785.title: Effect of NLRP3 inflammasome genes polymorphism on disease susceptibility and response to TNF-α inhibitors in Iraqi patients with rheumatoid arthritis

var_pheno_ann.Notes: In RA patients, CARD8 rs2043211 TT genotype (T allele–bearing variant homozygous genotype) was more frequent among non-responders to anti-TNF-α therapy (etanercept or infliximab) and associated with higher DAS-28 and higher TNF-α and IL-1β serum levels. Significant differences in genotype distribution between responders and non-responders (P<0.0001). Dominant vs recessive model analyses showed T-allele–bearing recessive model associated with higher disease activity and lower response.
var_pheno_ann.Sentence: CARD8 rs2043211 is associated with decreased Other:Response when treated with etanercept or infliximab in people with Disease:Rheumatoid arthritis.
Citations: "Thirty-four of 100 RA patients (14 etanercept and 20 infliximab) did not respond to anti-TNF-α therapy, while 66 (38 and 28) did."
"Significant difference was observed in CARD8 (rs2043211) genotypes between responders and non-responders (P < 0.0001)."

"Patients with CARD8 (rs2043211) A allele bearing genotypes (wild homozygous and heterozygous genotypes) associated with lower DAS- as compared to those with T allele bearing genotypes (Variant homozygous genotypes and heterozygous genotypes. This assume that CARD8 (rs2043211) variant genotypes are associated with lower response to anti-TNF-α treatments in RA patients."

var_pheno_ann.Notes: In RA patients, NLRP3 rs4612666 TT genotype (T allele–bearing variant homozygous genotype) and, more broadly, T allele–bearing genotypes were more common among non-responders to anti-TNF-α therapy (etanercept or infliximab) and associated with higher DAS-28 and higher TNF-α and IL-1β serum levels. Significant differences in genotype distribution between responders and non-responders (P<0.0001). Recessive model (T allele–bearing genotypes) associated with higher disease activity and lower response to anti-TNF-α drugs.
var_pheno_ann.Sentence: NLRP3 rs4612666 is associated with decreased Other:Response when treated with etanercept or infliximab in people with Disease:Rheumatoid arthritis.
Citations: Interestingly, this study revealed that CARD8 (rs2043211) and NLRP3 (rs4612666) variant genotypes are associated with lower response to anti-TNF-α drugs.

The influence of CARD8 rs2043211 and NLRP3 rs4612666 polymorphisms was stated after 3 months of RA treatment. T allele bearing genotypes (Variant homozygous genotypes and heterozygous genotypes) for CARD8 rs2043211 NLRP3 rs4612666 polymorphism had significantly higher DAS-28. Consequently, variant genotypes of CARD8 rs2043211 and NLRP3 rs4612666 were related with higher disease activity and lower response to TNF-inhibitors, also higher concentration of TNF-α and IL-1β.

Moreover, NLRP3 (rs4612666), C Allele bearing genotypes (wild homozygous and heterozygous genotypes) are associated with lower DAS-28 as compared with T allele bearing genotypes (Variant homozygous and heterozygous genotypes (P < 0.0001 and 0.003 respectively), this supposing that NLRP3 (rs4612666) variant genotypes are extremely associated with higher disease progression and lower response to anti-TNF-α drugs.

var_pheno_ann.Notes: CARD8 rs2043211 TT genotype was associated with higher DAS-28 scores and more active disease course after 3 months of anti-TNF-α therapy in RA patients. T allele–bearing genotypes (heterozygous and variant homozygous) were associated with higher disease activity compared with AA genotype. Recessive genetic model showed higher disease activity (P=0.029).
var_pheno_ann.Sentence: CARD8 rs2043211 is associated with increased Other:Disease activity when treated with etanercept or infliximab in people with Disease:Rheumatoid arthritis.
Citations: "CARD8 (rs2043211) TT genotype was more frequent in patients with higher DAS-28 (P < 0.0001) and higher TNF-α and IL-1β serum levels (P < 0.0001 for both)."

"Comparison of SNPs genetic models with disease activity, reveal that higher disease activity is associated with patients harboring CARD8 recessive genetic models (P = 0.029), wherein, higher disease activity was associated with heterozygous and variant homozygous genotypes (T allele bearing) of CARD8 SNP rs2043211 as compared with wild (AA) genotype. ... Higher response rate associated with dominant models of CARD8 SNP rs2043211 and NLRP3 SNP rs4612666 (P < 0.0001 and 0.001 respectively). While highly non response rate related with recessive models of these two SNPs (P < 0.0001 for both)."

var_pheno_ann.Notes: NLRP3 rs4612666 TT genotype and T allele–bearing genotypes were associated with higher DAS-28 scores and higher disease activity after 3 months of anti-TNF-α therapy in RA patients. Recessive model (CT+TT vs CC) associated with high disease activity (P=0.002). Variant genotypes were described as being extremely associated with higher disease progression and lower response to anti-TNF-α drugs.
var_pheno_ann.Sentence: NLRP3 rs4612666 is associated with increased Other:Disease activity when treated with etanercept or infliximab in people with Disease:Rheumatoid arthritis.
Citations: Interestingly, this study revealed that CARD8 (rs2043211) and NLRP3 (rs4612666) variant genotypes are associated with lower response to anti-TNF-α drugs.

Moreover, NLRP3 (rs4612666), C Allele bearing genotypes (wild homozygous and heterozygous genotypes) are associated with lower DAS-28 as compared with T allele bearing genotypes (Variant homozygous and heterozygous genotypes (P < 0.0001 and 0.003 respectively), this supposing that NLRP3 (rs4612666) variant genotypes are extremely associated with higher disease progression and lower response to anti-TNF-α drugs.

Comparison of SNPs genetic models with disease activity, reveal that higher disease activity is associated with patients harboring CARD8 recessive genetic models (P = 0.029), wherein, higher disease activity was associated with heterozygous and variant homozygous genotypes (T allele bearing) of CARD8 SNP rs2043211 as compared with wild (AA) genotype. Additionally, NLRP3 (rs4612666) recessive model is associated with high disease activity (P = 0.002), similarly, higher disease activity was associated with NLRP3 (rs4612666) heterozygous and variant homozygous genotypes (T allele bearing) as compared with wild (CC) genotype.

Authors concluded no significant association with RA susceptibility.
var_pheno_ann.Sentence: CARD8 rs2043211 is not associated with Other:Susceptibility to Disease:Rheumatoid arthritis in people with Disease:Rheumatoid arthritis.

"RA patients and controls had similar CARD8 rs2043211 and NLRP3 rs4612666 genotype distributions (P = 0.17 and 0.08 respectively), where no deviations from Hardy–Weinberg equilibrium were detected for the genotype distribution. In addition, patients and controls had comparable CARD8 (rs2043211) and NLRP3 allele frequencies, P = 0.059 and 0.879, respectively ([Table 6](#tbl6))."

"RA patients and controls had similar CARD8 rs2043211 and NLRP3 rs4612666 genotype distributions (P = 0.17 and 0.08 respectively), where no deviations from Hardy–Weinberg equilibrium were detected for the genotype distribution. In addition, patients and controls had comparable CARD8 (rs2043211) and NLRP3 allele frequencies, P = 0.059 and 0.879, respectively ([Table 6](#tbl6))."

"The goal of the study was to explore the impact of genetic factors on the susceptibility of RA. Selected SNP in the study CARD8 rs2043211 (A > T) and NLRP3 rs4612666 (T > C) have identified the significance of their role in RA pathogenesis in several previous studies. Our results indicate that the 2 SNPs were not associated with RA susceptibility."

var_drug_ann.Notes: In 65 HIV/TB adults on efavirenz plus rifampicin, mean 12-hour post-dose plasma efavirenz concentrations at weeks 6 and 12 of ART and 1 month after rifampicin discontinuation were 10.97 ± 2.32, 13.62 ± 4.21 and 8.48 ± 1.30 mg/L in TT patients, 3.43 ± 0.29, 3.35 ± 0.27 and 3.21 ± 0.22 mg/L in GT patients, and 2.88 ± 0.33, 2.45 ± 0.26 and 2.08 ± 0.16 mg/L in GG patients; TT vs GT or GG p < 0.0001 at all three time points.
var_drug_ann.Sentence: Genotype TT is associated with increased 12-hour post-dose plasma efavirenz concentration in patients with HIV infectious disease and Tuberculosis as compared to genotypes GG + GT.
Citations: "The mean 12-hour post-dose plasma efavirenz concentration in patients with TT genotype at weeks 6 and 12 of ART and 1 month after rifampicin discontinuation (10.97 ± 2.32, 13.62 ± 4.21 and 8.48 ± 1.30 mg/L, respectively) were significantly higher than those with GT (3.43 ± 0.29, 3.35 ± 0.27 and 3.21 ± 0.22 mg/L, respectively) (p < 0.0001) or GG genotypes (2.88 ± 0.33, 2.45 ± 0.26 and 2.08 ± 0.16 mg/L, respectively) (p < 0.0001)."

"The results indicated that the wide interindividual variability of efavirenz concentrations is strongly influenced by CYP2B6-516TT genotype by the finding of significantly higher plasma efavirenz concentration at weeks 6 and 12 of ART and 1 month after rifampicin discontinuation compared to those with GT or GG genotype."

var_drug_ann.Notes: In 59 HIV/TB adults on nevirapine plus rifampicin, mean 12-hour post-dose plasma nevirapine concentrations at weeks 6 and 12 of ART and 1 month after rifampicin discontinuation were 14.09 ± 9.49, 7.94 ± 2.76 and 9.44 ± 0.17 mg/L in TT patients, 5.65 ± 0.54, 5.58 ± 0.48 and 7.03 ± 0.64 mg/L in GT patients, and 5.42 ± 0.48, 5.34 ± 0.50 and 6.43 ± 0.64 mg/L in GG patients; overall TT vs others showed a trend, with p = 0.003 at week 6 and p = 0.409 and 0.448 at weeks 12 and post-rifampicin, respectively.
var_drug_ann.Sentence: Genotype TT is associated with increased 12-hour post-dose plasma nevirapine concentration in patients with HIV infectious disease and Tuberculosis as compared to genotypes GG + GT.

"Similar results were found in nevirapine group (Figure [1d, e, f](#F1)) in that the mean plasma drug concentration of patients with TT genotype at weeks 6 and 12 of ART and 1 month after rifampicin discontinuation (14.09 ± 9.49, 7.94 ± 2.76 and 9.44 ± 0.17 mg/L, respectively) tended to be higher than those with GT genotype (5.65 ± 0.54, 5.58 ± 0.48 and 7.03 ± 0.64 mg/L, respectively) or GG genotype (5.42 ± 0.48, 5.34 ± 0.50 and 6.43 ± 0.64 mg/L, respectively) (p = 0.003, p = 0.409 and p = 0.448, respectively)."
"CYP2B6-TT genotype had impact on plasma efavirenz and nevirapine concentrations, while rifampicin co-administration had only small effects."

var_drug_ann.Notes: At week 12 of ART in the efavirenz group, 88.89% (8/9) of TT, 77.42% (24/31) of GT, and 68% (17/25) of GG patients achieved plasma HIV-1 RNA <50 copies/mL; p = 0.430 for comparison among genotypes.
var_drug_ann.Sentence: Genotype TT is not associated with response to efavirenz in patients with HIV infectious disease and Tuberculosis as compared to genotypes GG + GT.
Citations: As shown in Table [2](#T2), when the proportion of patients with HIV-1 RNA level <50 copies/mL (log 1.69) were compared among *CYP2B6*-G516T genotypes at week 12 of ART, 88.89% (8/9) of patients with TT genotype in efavirenz group could achieve the HIV-1 RNA levels <50 copies/mL, which were higher than those with GT genotype (77.42%, 24/31) and GG genotype (68%, 17/25), although this difference was not statistically significant (p = 0.430).

With respect to possible correlation of the variations in plasma efavirenz and nevirapine levels with the treatment outcome, our results indicated that the patients with *CYP2B6 *516TT genotype had a higher frequency of viral load suppression at week 12 of ART than those with GT and GG genotype.

var_drug_ann.Notes: At week 12 of ART in the nevirapine group, 100% (2/2) of TT, 70.97% (23/31) of GT, and 60% (15/26) of GG patients achieved plasma HIV-1 RNA <50 copies/mL; p = 0.288 for comparison among genotypes.
var_drug_ann.Sentence: Genotype TT is not associated with response to nevirapine in patients with HIV infectious disease and Tuberculosis as compared to genotypes GG + GT.
Citations: As shown in Table [2](#T2), when the proportion of patients with HIV-1 RNA level <50 copies/mL (log 1.69) were compared among *CYP2B6*-G516T genotypes at week 12 of ART, 88.89% (8/9) of patients with TT genotype in efavirenz group could achieve the HIV-1 RNA levels <50 copies/mL, which were higher than those with GT genotype (77.42%, 24/31) and GG genotype (68%, 17/25), although this difference was not statistically significant (p = 0.430).
