PMC2859392.summary:
Study question and design:
This prospective pharmacogenetic analysis nested in the N2R randomized trial examined whether CYP2B6 and CYP3A4 polymorphisms affect efavirenz and nevirapine plasma concentrations in Thai adults with HIV/TB co‑infection receiving rifampicin-containing TB therapy. One hundred twenty‑four antiretroviral‑naïve patients on rifampicin for 4–6 weeks were started on standard-dose ART: efavirenz 600 mg once daily (n=65) or nevirapine 200 mg twice daily (after a 2‑week 200 mg once-daily lead‑in; n=59) plus lamivudine/stavudine. Patients had plasma NNRTI concentrations measured 12 hours post‑dose (C12) at week 6, week 12, and 1 month after stopping rifampicin. Seven SNPs were genotyped (CYP2B6: 516G>T, 777C>A, 415A>G, 1459C>T; CYP3A4: 566T>C, 878T>C, 1088C>T). Clinical outcomes (CD4, HIV‑1 RNA) were followed up to 48 weeks.

Key genotype frequencies:
- CYP2B6 516G>T in efavirenz group (n=65): GG 38.5%, GT 47.7%, TT 13.9%.
- CYP2B6 516G>T in nevirapine group (n=59): GG 44.1%, GT 52.5%, TT 3.4%.
- Other CYP2B6 and CYP3A4 SNPs showed little or no variation; only CYP2B6 516G>T and CYP3A4 878T>C could be meaningfully evaluated, and CYP3A4 data were limited by very few variant carriers.

Main pharmacokinetic findings (CYP2B6 516G>T):
1. Efavirenz (strong effect, consistent over time)
- Mean C12 (mg/L) at week 6 / week 12 / 1 month post‑rifampicin:
  • TT: 10.97 ± 2.32 / 13.62 ± 4.21 / 8.48 ± 1.30
  • GT: 3.43 ± 0.29 / 3.35 ± 0.27 / 3.21 ± 0.22
  • GG: 2.88 ± 0.33 / 2.45 ± 0.26 / 2.08 ± 0.16
- TT carriers had ~3–5‑fold higher efavirenz concentrations than GG/GT at all time points (p<0.0001 versus either genotype).
- Despite concomitant rifampicin—a strong CYP inducer—CYP2B6 516TT clearly identified poor metabolizers with markedly elevated efavirenz levels.

2. Nevirapine (similar direction, weaker statistical support)
- Mean C12 (mg/L) at week 6 / week 12 / 1 month post‑rifampicin:
  • TT: 14.09 ± 9.49 / 7.94 ± 2.76 / 9.44 ± 0.17
  • GT: 5.65 ± 0.54 / 5.58 ± 0.48 / 7.03 ± 0.64
  • GG: 5.42 ± 0.48 / 5.34 ± 0.50 / 6.43 ± 0.64
- Trend toward higher nevirapine levels in TT carriers: significant at week 6 (p=0.003), not significant at week 12 (p=0.409) or 1 month post‑rifampicin (p=0.448), likely due to the very small number of TT subjects (n=2 in nevirapine arm).

Effect of rifampicin versus genetics:
- When not stratified by genotype, for the entire efavirenz group:
  • Mean C12 decreased after rifampicin discontinuation: 4.26 mg/L (week 6) → 3.5 mg/L (1 month post‑rifampicin); p=0.043 for week 6 vs post‑TB.
- For nevirapine:
  • Mean C12 increased after rifampicin discontinuation: 5.83 mg/L (week 6) → 6.84 mg/L (1 month post‑rifampicin); p=0.034 (week 6 vs post‑TB), p<0.001 (week 12 vs post‑TB).
- Nonetheless, the authors conclude that the magnitude of rifampicin’s effect on efavirenz and nevirapine exposure was much smaller than the impact of CYP2B6 516TT; rifampicin did not “normalize” the poor metabolizer phenotype.

Therapeutic range and safety implications:
- All genotype groups maintained efavirenz and nevirapine concentrations above conventional minimum target thresholds (efavirenz ≥1 mg/L; nevirapine ≥3.4 mg/L) even during rifampicin co‑therapy.
- TT carriers had substantially higher efavirenz and likely higher nevirapine levels, raising theoretical concern for toxicity (e.g., CNS effects, rash, hepatotoxicity). In this study, TT patients generally tolerated therapy, but seven participants overall left the parent trial due to adverse events; genotypes of those individuals were not evaluated here.

CYP3A4 878T>C:
- Very few heterozygous carriers (3 efavirenz, 1 nevirapine). These individuals tended to have higher efavirenz and nevirapine concentrations than TT homozygotes, but numbers were too small for statistical analysis, so no firm conclusion on CYP3A4’s effect was possible.

Virologic and immunologic outcomes:
- CD4+ T‑cell counts: increased robustly and similarly across CYP2B6 genotypes through 48 weeks in both efavirenz and nevirapine arms; no significant genotype effect on CD4 recovery.
- Viral load suppression (HIV‑1 RNA <50 copies/mL at week 12):
  • Efavirenz: GG 68% (17/25), GT 77.4% (24/31), TT 88.9% (8/9); p=0.430.
  • Nevirapine: GG 60% (15/26), GT 71.0% (23/31), TT 100% (2/2); p=0.288.
- There was a non‑significant trend toward higher early suppression rates in TT carriers, consistent with higher drug exposure, but by weeks 24–48 almost all patients achieved undetectable viral loads regardless of genotype.

Clinical and pharmacogenomic implications:
- CYP2B6 516G>T is a major determinant of efavirenz exposure and a relevant determinant of nevirapine exposure in Thai HIV/TB patients, even in the presence of potent CYP induction by rifampicin.
- Standard efavirenz 600 mg/day and nevirapine 400 mg/day appear sufficient to maintain therapeutic levels during rifampicin co‑treatment across genotypes in this population.
- CYP2B6 516TT identifies individuals at risk for very high efavirenz (and possibly nevirapine) levels; in other settings, genotype‑guided dose reduction has been shown to reduce CNS toxicity. The study supports considering CYP2B6 genotyping when possible for optimizing efavirenz (and perhaps nevirapine) dosing, especially in populations with higher TT frequency.
- Rifampicin modestly lowers efavirenz and modestly lowers then raises nevirapine concentrations after discontinuation, but its effect is smaller than genetic variability at CYP2B6 516.

Limitations:
- Single mid‑dose (C12) sampling; full pharmacokinetic profiles (AUC, Cmax, clearance) were not obtained.
- Small sample size of CYP2B6 516TT (especially in the nevirapine arm) and of CYP3A4 variant carriers limits power for some comparisons.
- Adverse event data were not linked to genotype, so tolerability of high concentrations in TT carriers cannot be fully assessed.

Overall conclusion:
In rifampicin‑treated Thai adults with HIV/TB co‑infection, CYP2B6 516TT strongly elevates efavirenz and, to a lesser extent, nevirapine concentrations, whereas rifampicin co‑administration exerts only modest influence on NNRTI levels. Genotype‑driven variability in exposure is much larger than rifampicin’s inducing effect. Standard dosing achieved effective virologic suppression across genotypes, but CYP2B6 516TT remains an important marker for high NNRTI exposure and a potential target for individualized dosing.

var_drug_ann.Sentence: Genotype HLA-A*31:01-positive Is Associated with increased risk of carbamazepine-induced hypersensitivity syndrome or maculopapular exanthems in children with seizure disorders as compared to HLA-A*31:01-negative.

Three of six patients (50%) with CBZ-HSS carried HLA-A*31:01, whereas only three (3.3%) of the 91 CBZ-tolerant controls carried the allele, resulting in a very strong association with CBZ-HSS (OR: 26.4; P=0.0025; [Table 2](#T2)). A significant association was also observed with CBZ-induced MPE, with six of 26 (23.1%) CBZ-MPE cases carrying HLA-A*31:01 (OR: 8.6; P=0.0037; [Table 2](#T2)). HLA-A*31:01 was thus very strongly associated with CBZ-HSS or MPE in a combined analysis of the two reactions (OR: 11.2; P=2.6×10^−4^; [Table 2](#T2)), with nine (28.1%) of the cases carrying HLA-A*31:01.
HLA-A*31:01 was associated with carbamazepine-induced hypersensitivity syndrome and maculopapular exanthems also in children with diverse ancestries.

var_drug_ann.Notes: European-only subgroup: among 20 CBZ hypersensitivity cases and 65 CBZ-tolerant controls with ≥3 European grandparents, 4 (20%) vs 2 (3.1%) carried HLA-A*31:01; OR 7.62 (95% CI 0.99–91.40), P=0.025.
var_drug_ann.Sentence: Genotype HLA-A*31:01-positive Is Associated with increased risk of carbamazepine-induced hypersensitivity reactions in European children with seizure disorders as compared to HLA-A*31:01-negative.

Similar results were observed for the association of HLA-A*31:01 with CBZ hypersensitivity as for the full cohort, with 20% of CBZ cases carrying HLA-A*31:01 (OR: 7.62; P=0.025; [Table 3](#T3)). As in the full cohort, a stronger association was observed when only considering patients with CBZ-HSS or MPE (OR: 10.05; P=0.013; [Table 3](#T3)).

Interestingly, rs1061235 was also overrepresented in hypersensitivity cases after excluding HLA-A*31:01-positive children (OR: 5.83; P=0.033; Supplementary Table 1), resulting in very similar effect sizes of the associations with HSS and MPE for HLA-A*31:01 and rs1061235.”

var_drug_ann.Notes: Across all CBZ hypersensitivity phenotypes (42 cases), 14 (33.3%) were rs1061235T carriers vs 6 of 91 (6.6%) controls; OR 6.96 (95% CI 2.25–24.32), P=1.5×10−4.

When considering all CBZ hypersensitivity reactions combined, a highly significant association of HLA-A*31:01 was observed (OR: 7.85; P=0.0016; [Table 2](#T2)), even though the effect size was reduced compared to an analysis only including HSS and MPE cases. On the other hand, HLA-B*15:02 was not significantly overrepresented in the CBZ cases overall. In a combined analysis of both risk variants, a strong association was observed with all CBZ-induced hypersensitivity reactions (OR: 8.14; P=2.6×10^−4^; [Table 2](#T2)).

Overall, 20 (15%) children treated with CBZ carried the T allele of rs1061235, a single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) previously shown to be in complete linkage disequilibrium with HLA-A*31:01 in Europeans ([30](#R30)).

On the other hand, HLA-B*15:02 was not significantly overrepresented in the CBZ cases overall."

var_drug_ann.Notes: Combined genetic test (HLA-A*31:01 or HLA-B*15:02 positive) across all CBZ hypersensitivity reactions: 12 of 42 (28.6%) cases vs 4 of 87–91 (4.6%) controls carried at least one risk allele; combined OR 8.14 (95% CI 2.25–37.34), P=2.6×10−4; positive likelihood ratio 6.21 with estimated post-test risk for hypersensitivity of 25–41% at baseline risk 5–10%.
var_drug_ann.Sentence: Genotype HLA-A*31:01- or HLA-B*15:02-positive Is Associated with increased risk of carbamazepine-induced hypersensitivity reactions in children with seizure disorders as compared to HLA-A*31:01- and HLA-B*15:02-negative.
Citations: In a combined analysis of both risk variants, a strong association was observed with all CBZ-induced hypersensitivity reactions (OR: 8.14; P=2.6×10^−4^; [Table 2](#T2)). Overall, 12 of 42 (28.6%) CBZ cases carried HLA-A*31:01 or HLA-B*15:02, whereas only four (4.6%) CBZ-tolerant patients were positive for either risk variant. Using an estimated incidence of CBZ-induced hypersensitivity reactions (pre-test probability) of 5–10%, the positive post-test probability of a combined genetic test for both risk variants, based on the positive likelihood ratio of 6.21 observed here, was estimated as 25–41%, with a negative post-test probability of 3.8–7.7%.

In conclusion, these findings demonstrate that HLA-A*31:01 and HLA-B*15:02 are predictive of CBZ-induced hypersensitivity reactions in children and that HLA-A*31:01 is a relevant marker in patients of various ancestries.

Overall, our findings were in agreement with previous studies, suggesting similar genetic associations in children and adults and an increased risk of CBZ hypersensitivity in children carrying these risk variants.

var_drug_ann.Notes: Combined genetic test (HLA-A*31:01 or HLA-B*15:02 positive) for CBZ-HSS/MPE (32 cases) vs controls: combined OR 7.94 (95% CI 2.00–38.55), P=8.9×10−5, indicating strong association of either risk allele with these cutaneous hypersensitivity reactions.

PMC3839910.summary:
Study question and design:
This Canadian, multicenter, pediatric pharmacogenomics case–control study evaluated whether HLA-A*31:01 and HLA-B*15:02 predict carbamazepine (CBZ) hypersensitivity in children of diverse ancestries. Forty‑two children with CBZ hypersensitivity (9 SJS/TEN, 6 HSS, 26 maculopapular exanthems [MPE], 1 AGEP) and 91 CBZ-tolerant controls (≥8 weeks CBZ without reaction) were genotyped. Five oxcarbazepine (OXC) hypersensitivity cases were explored descriptively.

Genotyping:
- HLA-B*15:02 was directly typed with a commercial kit.
- HLA-A*31:01 was assessed by sequence-based typing and by the proxy SNP rs1061235, known to be in complete LD with HLA-A*31:01 in Europeans.

Key findings – HLA-A*31:01:
- Strong association with CBZ-induced HSS:
  - 3/6 HSS cases (50%) vs 3/91 controls (3.3%) carried HLA-A*31:01.
  - OR 26.4; P = 0.0025.
- Significant association with CBZ-induced MPE:
  - 6/26 MPE cases (23.1%) vs 3/91 controls (3.3%).
  - OR 8.6; P = 0.0037.
- Combined HSS + MPE:
  - 9/32 cases (28.1%) vs 3/91 controls (3.3%).
  - OR 11.2; P = 2.6×10⁻⁴.
- No association with CBZ-SJS/TEN (0/9 SJS/TEN carriers of HLA-A*31:01; OR ~1, P = 1.0), though numbers were small.
- Overall CBZ hypersensitivity (all phenotypes): 9/42 cases (21.4%) vs 3/91 controls (3.3%), OR 7.85; P = 0.0016.

Proxy SNP rs1061235:
- rs1061235T also associated with HSS and MPE with similar effect sizes (combined HSS/MPE: OR 9.45; P = 2.6×10⁻⁵).
- rs1061235T remained overrepresented among cases even after excluding HLA-A*31:01 carriers, particularly in some non‑European ancestries (often tagging HLA-A*33:03), indicating that rs1061235 is not a reliable universal proxy for HLA-A*31:01 in multiethnic populations.

Key findings – HLA-B*15:02:
- Strong association with CBZ-induced SJS/TEN only:
  - 3/9 SJS/TEN cases (33.3%) vs 1/87 genotyped controls (1.1%).
  - OR 38.6; P = 0.0022.
- All HLA-B*15:02–positive SJS/TEN patients reported Asian ancestry (Chinese, Filipino, Sri Lankan, etc.), confirming ethnic enrichment and extending relevance to Sri Lankan origin.
- No HLA-B*15:02 carriers among HSS or MPE cases; no association with these phenotypes.
- Across all CBZ hypersensitivity phenotypes combined, HLA-B*15:02 was not significantly enriched due to its specificity for SJS/TEN and low allele frequency.

Combined analysis:
- Considering HLA-A*31:01 or HLA-B*15:02 as a combined test:
  - 12/42 CBZ hypersensitivity cases (28.6%) vs 4/87–91 controls (≈4–5%) carried at least one risk allele.
  - Combined OR 8.14; P = 2.6×10⁻⁴.
  - Positive likelihood ratio ≈6.2.
  - Assuming a baseline CBZ hypersensitivity risk of 5–10%, a positive test raises post-test risk to ~25–41%, whereas a negative test reduces it to ~3.8–7.7%.
- The variants are neither necessary nor sufficient: most carriers tolerate CBZ, and some hypersensitivity cases lack both risk alleles.

Ancestry insights:
- HLA-B*15:02 carriers were exclusively of Asian origin (mostly Chinese, one Filipino, one Sri Lankan), consistent with known population frequencies.
- HLA-A*31:01 carriers were observed across multiple ancestries, including European, Aboriginal Canadian, and Latin American, confirming its broad global relevance.
- Subgroup analysis restricted to children with predominantly European ancestry (≥3 European grandparents) replicated the HLA-A*31:01 signal:
  - All CBZ hypersensitivity: 4/20 cases (20%) vs 2/65 controls (3.1%), OR 7.62; P = 0.025.
  - HSS/MPE: 4/16 (25%) vs 2/65 (3.1%), OR 10.05; P = 0.013.

OXC hypersensitivity (exploratory):
- Five OXC cases (2 SJS, 3 MPE): no clear pattern for HLA-A*31:01 or HLA-B*15:02, and sample size too small to conclude.

Clinical implications:
- This is the first study to clearly demonstrate HLA-A*31:01 as a risk factor for CBZ-induced HSS and MPE in children and in a multiethnic North American setting, including European, Aboriginal, and Latin American ancestries.
- HLA-B*15:02 is strongly and specifically associated with CBZ-SJS/TEN in pediatric patients of Asian ancestry, in line with adult data.
- Given the severity of SJS/TEN and HSS, and the availability of alternative antiepileptic drugs, the authors advocate pre-prescription genotyping for both HLA-A*31:01 and HLA-B*15:02 in all children (and adults) considered for CBZ, irrespective of reported ancestry, especially in ethnically admixed populations.
- rs1061235 should not be used alone as a universal surrogate for HLA-A*31:01 in diverse populations; direct HLA typing is preferable where possible.

Limitations:
- Modest sample size, particularly for SJS/TEN and HSS, limits precision of phenotype-specific odds ratios and may contribute to lack of observed association of HLA-A*31:01 with SJS/TEN.
- Ancestry based on self-report without genetic confirmation, and controls skewed toward European origin.
- No large OXC-tolerant control group to examine cross-reactivity.

Overall conclusion:
HLA-A*31:01 is a robust predictor of CBZ-induced HSS and MPE in children across multiple ancestries, while HLA-B*15:02 is a strong, specific marker for CBZ-induced SJS/TEN in Asian children. Combined HLA-A*31:01/HLA-B*15:02 testing in pediatric practice has substantial potential to reduce severe CBZ hypersensitivity, though further work is needed to refine risk prediction and clarify the role of HLA-A*31:01 in SJS/TEN and AGEP.

Citations: Among the 48 escitalopram-treated participants who provided samples for pharmacokinetic analysis, CYP2C19 metabolizer phenotype had a significant effect on the dose-normalized AUC0–24 (p = 0.025), Ctrough (p = 0.013), and t1/2 (p = 0.0008) of escitalopram (Fig. 1).

Analysis of associations between CYP2C19 phenotype (including IM, NM, RM, and UM phenotypes) and pharmacokinetic parameters. CYP2C19 phenotype was associated with (A) AUC0–24 (p = 0.025), (C) Ctrough (p = 0.013), and (D) elimination half-life (t1/2; p = 0.0008), but not (B) the Cmax (p = 0.057) of escitalopram. AUC0–24, 24-hour area under the curve; Cmax, maximum concentration; Ctrough, trough concentration; IM, intermediate metabolizer; NM, normal metabolizer; RM, rapid metabolizer; UM, ultrarapid metabolizer.
Slower CYP2C19 metabolizers also tended to have higher dose-normalized Cmax, though this relationship was not statistically significant (p = 0.057).

Slower CYP2C19 metabolizers tended to have greater TEASAP “self-injury, suicidality, and harm to others” subscale scores (F = 2.32, df = 2, p = 0.09), though CYP2C19 phenotype was not associated with increases in other TEASAP subscales scores (p = 0.39–0.92), maximum PAERS score (p = 0.27), or hyperarousal events (p = 0.60; Table 2).

Comparison between an aggregate group with normal or faster than normal metabolism (NM or UM) and an aggregate group with slower than normal CYP2D6 metabolism (IM and PM) revealed that participants with slower than normal CYP2D6 metabolism had significantly greater TEASAP disinhibition and impulsivity subscale scores than those with normal or faster than normal metabolism (mean = 3.0 vs. 1.1, *p* = 0.02).

PMC10880264.summary:
Objective:
To examine how pharmacogenetic variation in CYP2C19, CYP2D6, HTR2A and SLC6A4 influences escitalopram pharmacokinetics and treatment‑emergent adverse events in depressed and/or anxious adolescents who have a first‑degree relative with bipolar I disorder (i.e., are at familial high risk for BD).

Design and population:
- Double‑blind RCT parent study (psychotherapy + escitalopram vs psychotherapy + placebo); this pharmacogenetic analysis focuses only on the escitalopram‑treated arm.
- Youth aged 12–17 years, antidepressant‑naïve, with clinically significant depression and/or anxiety and at least one first‑degree relative with bipolar I disorder.
- N = 66 escitalopram‑treated participants with pharmacogenetic data; N = 48 of these also had escitalopram serum levels and PK modeling.

Treatment and assessments:
- Escitalopram 5 mg → 10 mg → target 20 mg/day (max 30 mg), flexible titration.
- Adverse outcomes captured by:
  - Clinician‑defined “hyperarousal event” (CGI‑Severity of Activation + CGAS criteria).
  - Pediatric Adverse Events Rating Scale (PAERS; 13 arousal‑related items, maximum severity after baseline).
  - Treatment‑Emergent Activation and Suicidality Assessment Profile (TEASAP) caregiver‑reported subscales: (1) self‑injury/suicidality/harm to others, (2) mania, (3) akathisia/hyperkinesis/somatic anxiety, (4) disinhibition/impulsivity, (5) irritability.
- Genotyping (Myriad panel): CYP2C19, CYP2D6, HTR2A −1438G>A (rs6311) and SLC6A4 5‑HTTLPR; CYP phenotypes assigned per CPIC.
- Escitalopram PK (one or limited samples) modeled using Bayesian population PK (MwPharm, Strawn et al model) to estimate Cmax, Ctrough, AUC0–24 and t1/2; PK compared across CYP phenotypes (dose‑normalized for gene–PK analyses; non‑normalized for exposure–AE analyses).

Key pharmacokinetic findings:
1. CYP2C19 strongly influences escitalopram exposure in youth.
- Phenotype distribution (PK subset, n=48): IM 21%, NM 50%, RM 27%, UM 2%; no poor metabolizers.
- Slower CYP2C19 metabolism (IM > NM > RM/UM) was associated with:
  - Higher dose‑normalized AUC0–24 (p = 0.025).
  - Higher dose‑normalized Ctrough (p = 0.013).
  - Longer escitalopram half‑life (t1/2; p = 0.0008).
- Trend toward higher dose‑normalized Cmax in slower metabolizers (p = 0.057).
- Confirms CPIC guidance: CYP2C19, not CYP2D6, is the primary PK driver for escitalopram in youth.

2. CYP2D6 does not measurably affect escitalopram parent‑drug PK.
- Phenotypes: PM 6%, IM 23%, NM 65%, UM 3%; 2 indeterminate.
- No significant associations between CYP2D6 phenotype and dose‑normalized AUC, Cmax, Ctrough, or t1/2 (all p > 0.48).
- Consistent with CYP2D6 having only a minor role in parent escitalopram clearance.

3. Escitalopram exposure vs. adverse events.
- Escitalopram Cmax and AUC0–24 (non–dose‑normalized) were not significantly associated with:
  - Hyperarousal events, nor
  - TEASAP subscale changes.
- There was a non‑significant trend for higher exposure to be associated with *lower* PAERS scores (p ≈ 0.11), opposite to the prior hypothesis that higher levels would drive more side effects.

Pharmacogenetic associations with adverse events:

CYP2C19 → AEs
- Despite clear PK effects, CYP2C19 phenotype was *not* significantly associated with:
  - Hyperarousal event frequency.
  - PAERS max scores.
  - TEASAP mania, akathisia, disinhibition, or irritability subscales.
- There was a non‑significant trend for higher TEASAP self‑injury/suicidality/harm‑to‑others scores in slower CYP2C19 metabolizers (p = 0.09), but this did not reach conventional significance and no poor metabolizers were present.

CYP2D6 → activation‑like AEs (novel signal)
- Slower CYP2D6 metabolizers (PM/IM) showed more SSRI‑like activation symptoms despite similar parent‑drug PK:
  - TEASAP akathisia/hyperkinesis/somatic anxiety subscale: significantly higher in slower CYP2D6 phenotypes (p = 0.015 across PM/IM/NM/UM).
  - When grouped as “slower than normal” (PM+IM) vs “normal/faster” (NM+UM), slower CYP2D6 was also associated with:
    - Higher disinhibition/impulsivity scores (mean 3.0 vs 1.1, p = 0.02).
    - Trends toward higher mania and akathisia/hyperkinesis/somatic anxiety scores (p ≈ 0.07–0.08).
- CYP2D6 phenotype was not associated with overall PAERS scores or hyperarousal event incidence.
- Interpretation: CYP2D6 may modulate *activation‑type behavioral AEs* independent of parent escitalopram levels—possibly by altering exposure to the active metabolite desmethylescitalopram, which is preferentially cleared by CYP2D6 and has a distinct pharmacodynamic profile (e.g., some NET binding, different receptor activities).

HTR2A → suicidality/harm‑related behaviors
- Genotype groups: 44% G/G, 56% A allele carriers (A/A or A/G).
- A allele carriers (A/A + A/G) exhibited significantly greater increases in TEASAP “self‑injury, suicidality, and harm to others” scores than G/G homozygotes (p = 0.017).
- No significant effect of HTR2A genotype on:
  - Other TEASAP subscales (mania, akathisia, disinhibition, irritability).
  - PAERS total.
  - Categorical hyperarousal events.
- This contrasts with earlier work where G/G was more associated with somatic side effects (e.g., nausea, dizziness) on SSRIs; here, A‑carriers appear at higher risk for high‑risk/suicidality‑related behaviors under escitalopram.
- Suggests HTR2A may differentially predict somatic vs psychiatric AEs across genotypes and drugs.

SLC6A4 → no association with AEs in this cohort
- Genotype distribution: S/S 24%, L/S 56%, L/L 20%.
- No significant associations between SLC6A4 S/S vs L‑carriers (L/L+L/S) and:
  - TEASAP subscales.
  - PAERS.
  - Hyperarousal events.
- This negative finding contrasts with prior studies implicating S/S in greater activation, mania‑like symptoms, or poorer SSRI response, but the current sample was relatively small.

Hyperarousal events
- 14 escitalopram‑treated participants experienced a clinician‑defined hyperarousal event; 12 had genotype data; 5 had PK data.
- No clear pharmacokinetic predictor (Cmax, AUC) or robust pharmacogenetic predictor of these discrete events was identified, likely due to low numbers and under‑representation of hyperarousal cases in the PK subset.

Clinical and research implications:
1. CYP2C19:
   - Strongly shapes escitalopram exposure in high‑risk youth, supporting CPIC‑style dose adjustment in pediatrics.
   - However, within this modestly sized cohort lacking CYP2C19 poor metabolizers, CYP2C19 phenotype did not significantly predict activation or other escitalopram‑related AEs.

2. CYP2D6:
   - Does *not* materially affect escitalopram parent‑drug PK, but slower metabolizers showed more akathisia‑like and disinhibition symptoms.
   - Raises the hypothesis that CYP2D6‑mediated handling of active metabolites (e.g., desmethylescitalopram) could influence behavioral activation independent of parent‑drug exposure.
   - Clinically, youth at familial risk for BD who are CYP2D6 slower metabolizers may warrant closer monitoring for akathisia/activation and impulsivity when exposed to escitalopram or related SSRIs.

3. HTR2A:
   - A‑allele carriers (A/A or A/G) appear more vulnerable to increases in caregiver‑reported self‑injury/suicidality/harm‑to‑others under escitalopram.
   - If replicated, HTR2A could be used as an additional risk marker for SSRI‑associated suicidal or aggressive behaviors in high‑risk youth, distinct from CYP‑based PK considerations.

4. SLC6A4:
   - No AE signal in this small cohort; does not rule out effects on efficacy or on other phenotypes but suggests that, at least for escitalopram‑induced activation in familial‑risk youth, SLC6A4 is not a major determinant.

5. General:
   - The overall AE burden did not clearly correlate with escitalopram exposure (Cmax/AUC), suggesting that idiosyncratic pharmacodynamic mechanisms and metabolite effects may be more important than steady‑state parent‑drug levels for activation‑like AEs in this context.

Limitations:
- Small sample size for pharmacogenetic subgroup analyses, especially for extreme CYP phenotypes (no CYP2C19 PMs, few CYP2D6 PMs/UMs).
- Only 48 had PK data and only 5 of 14 hyperarousal cases contributed PK samples → limited power to detect exposure–AE relationships.
- Multiple statistical tests performed without correction → risk of type I error; findings should be considered preliminary and hypothesis‑generating.
- Single time‑point PK modeling and no direct measurement of desmethylescitalopram or didesmethylescitalopram.

Overall conclusion:
- In high‑risk adolescents treated with escitalopram, CYP2C19 phenotype robustly influences escitalopram pharmacokinetics but did not, in this small sample, translate into clear differences in activation or other AEs.
- CYP2D6 slower‑metabolizer status and HTR2A A‑allele genotypes were associated with more activation‑like and suicidality/harm‑related behavioral AEs, respectively, despite minimal effect of CYP2D6 on parent‑drug PK.
- These preliminary findings suggest that integrating CYP2D6 and HTR2A into pharmacogenomic risk assessment may help identify youth at elevated risk for escitalopram‑associated activation and self‑harm/aggression, but larger, prospectively powered cohorts are needed before changing clinical practice.

Citations: Slower CYP2D6 phenotypes were significantly associated with greater increases in TEASAP Akathisia, Hyperkinesis, and Somatic Anxiety subscale (*p* = 0.015; [Fig. 2](#f2)), but not with other TEASAP subscales (*p* = 0.14–0.99), maximum PAERS score (*p* = 0.51), or hyperarousal events (*p* = 0.55; [Table 2](#tb2)).

Comparison between an aggregate group with normal or faster than normal metabolism (NM or UM) and an aggregate group with slower than normal CYP2D6 metabolism (IM and PM) revealed that participants with slower than normal CYP2D6 metabolism had significantly greater TEASAP disinhibition and impulsivity subscale scores than those with normal or faster than normal metabolism (mean = 3.0 vs. 1.1, *p* = 0.02).

Our study suggests that the pharmacokinetics of escitalopram are influenced by CYP2C19 but not CYP2D6 phenotype. However, CYP2D6 phenotype and *HTR2A* genotype may influence the risk of adverse effects of escitalopram. Specifically, individuals with slower CYP2D6 phenotypes may be at increased risk of experiencing akathisia or worsening impulsivity.

HTR2A A/A and A/G genotypes were associated with increased TEASAP “self-injury, suicidality, and harm to others” subscale scores (p = 0.017). Escitalopram maximum concentration, AUC0–24, CYP2C19 phenotype, and SLC6A4 genotype were not associated with adverse events.
Participants with HTR2A A/A or A/G genotypes had a greater increase in TEASAP “Self-injury, Suicidality, and Harm to Others” subscale scores relative to those with HTR2A G/G genotypes (p = 0.017).

Adverse outcomes of interest were also influenced by HTR2A genotype, as we found greater increases in caregiver reports of high-risk behaviors (i.e., self-harm, suicidality, and harm to others) among those with HTR2A A/A and A/G genotypes.

var_drug_ann.Notes: Delayed diarrhea, neutropenia, and leukopenia differed significantly among UGT1A1*6 GG, GA, and AA genotypes despite genotype-guided dose reduction (diarrhea p=0.000; neutropenia p=0.000; leukopenia p=0.003). Grade 3/4 diarrhea, neutropenia, and leukopenia occurred in 100% (5/5) of AA patients versus 2%, 19%, and 24% in GG and 23%, 31%, and 31% in GA patients, respectively. Authors conclude that patients with the AA genotype could not tolerate severe toxicity even with reduced doses of irinotecan and irinotecan may not be suitable for AA subtype.

var_drug_ann.Notes: Across UGT1A1*6 subgroups (GG, GA, AA), the distribution of diarrhea grades differed significantly (p=0.000). Grade 3/4 diarrhea: GG 1/67 (2%), GA 8/35 (23%), AA 5/5 (100%). Authors describe a stepwise increase in adverse reactions from wild-type to heterozygous to homozygous mutants.

Citations: However, diarrhea (*p *= 0.000), neutropenia (*p *= 0.000), and leukopenia (*p *= 0.003) were significantly different among *UGT1A1*6* subgroups ([Table 3](#table3-15330338241236658)). Additionally, grade 3/4 diarrhea, neutropenia, and leukopenia were significantly more common in AA genotype patients compared to GG (2%, 19%, and 24%) or GA (23%, 31%, and 31%) genotype patients, suggesting that that patients with the AA genotype could not tolerate severe toxicity even with reduced doses of irinotecan.

*UGT1A1*6* gene polymorphism is significantly related to delayed diarrhea and neutropenia, which is consistent with the existing research conclusions. The incidence of adverse reactions gradually increases in patients with wild-type, mutant heterozygous and mutant homozygous. However, we found that for homozygous mutant patients, even if 40% irinotecan dose reduction, severe toxicity still occurred.

Authors state there was no relation between PFS and UGT1A1*6.

In this study, it did not affect the PFS (GG type 4.8 m vs GA type 4.9 m vs AA type 4.4 m; *p* = 0.5249), or OS (GG type 9.3 m vs GA type 9.3 m vs AA type NA; *p* = 0.6821).

The median PFS was 4.7 months (95% CI = 4.3-5.3) in the *TA6/TA6* group, 5.0 months (95% CI = 4.1-6.2) in the *TA6/TA7* group, 5.3 months (95% CI = 2.8-NA) in the *TA7/TA7* group, 4.8 months (95% CI = 4.1-5.5) in the GG group, 4.9 months (95% CI = 4.4-5.3) in the GA group, and 4.4 months (95% CI = 3.9-NA) in the AA group ([Figure 1A](#fig1-15330338241236658), B).

var_drug_ann.Notes: Overall survival (OS) did not differ among UGT1A1*6 GG, GA, and AA genotypes after dose adjustment: GG 9.3 months (95% CI 8.8-10.9), GA 9.3 months (95% CI 8.7-NA), AA NA (95% CI 8.8-NA), p=0.6821. Authors conclude there was no relation between OS and UGT1A1*6.
var_drug_ann.Sentence: Genotypes AA + GA are not associated with overall survival under irinotecan-based second-line treatment in patients with advanced gastric cancer as compared to genotype GG.
Citations: In this cohort, we can see that the PFS and OS of 5 patients with AA genotype showed no difference from GG or GA genotype after timely changing chemotherapy regimen. In addition, GC with single allele variation or two alleles variation also showed no significant difference in PFS and OS ([Figure 2](#fig2-15330338241236658)).

In the present study, univariable and multivariate analysis revealed no relation between PFS and *UGT1A1*6* or *UGT1A1*28* ([Table 4](#table4-15330338241236658)). However, the univariable analysis showed a significant association between OS and tumor differentiation, Lauren classification, surgery and metastasis sites, while no relation between OS and *UGT1A1*6* or *UGT1A1*28* ([Table 5](#table5-15330338241236658)).
In this study, it did not affect the PFS (GG type 4.8 m vs GA type 4.9 m vs AA type 4.4 m; *p* = 0.5249), or OS (GG type 9.3 m vs GA type 9.3 m vs AA type NA; *p* = 0.6821).

var_drug_ann.Notes: Among UGT1A1*28 TA6/TA6, TA6/TA7, and TA7/TA7 genotypes, no significant differences were observed in diarrhea (p=0.136), neutropenia (p=0.991), leukopenia (p=0.857), thrombocytopenia (p=0.450), or hemoglobin reduction (p=0.151). Authors state that there was no significant difference in the incidence of AEs in gastric cancer patients with different UGT1A1*28 genotypes, likely influenced by irinotecan dose reduction.

However, diarrhea (*p *= 0.000), neutropenia (*p *= 0.000), and leukopenia (*p *= 0.003) were significantly different among *UGT1A1*6* subgroups ([Table 3](#table3-15330338241236658)).

It was found that there was no significant difference in the incidence of AEs in GC patients with different *UGT1A1*28* genotypes. The incidence of these grade 3-4 toxicities was not similar to previous studies of irinotecan.^4,6^ Irinotecan dose reduction may influence the toxicity of each *UGT1A1*28* subgroup.

PMC10946077.summary:
Study question and design:
This single-center retrospective study evaluated whether pre-treatment UGT1A1*6 genotyping can safely individualize irinotecan dosing as second-line therapy for advanced gastric cancer, and whether genotype-guided dosing affects efficacy.

Patients and genotyping:
- 110 Chinese patients with advanced gastric cancer (GC) received second-line chemotherapy after fluoropyrimidine + platinum regimens.
- UGT1A1*6 and UGT1A1*28 were genotyped before treatment.
- Genotype distribution:
  - UGT1A1*6: GG (wild-type) 60.9%, GA 31.8%, AA 7.3%.
  - UGT1A1*28: TA6/TA6 70.9%, TA6/TA7 25.5%, TA7/TA7 3.6%.

Genotype-guided regimen:
- Irinotecan q3w, given on days 1 and 8 of each cycle, with dose based on UGT1A1*6:
  - GG: 125 mg/m² (full dose).
  - GA: 100 mg/m² (~20% reduction).
  - AA: 75 mg/m² (~40% reduction), or early switch to paclitaxel if severe toxicity; 3 AA patients were started directly on paclitaxel 125 mg/m².
- Total: 107 patients received irinotecan; 3 AA patients received only paclitaxel.

Efficacy outcomes:
- Median follow-up: 9.0 months.
- For the whole cohort:
  - Median PFS: 4.4 months.
  - Median OS: 8.7 months.
- PFS by UGT1A1*6:
  - GG: 4.8 months (95% CI 4.1–5.5).
  - GA: 4.9 months (95% CI 4.4–5.3).
  - AA: 4.4 months (95% CI 3.9–NA).
- OS by UGT1A1*6:
  - GG: 9.3 months (95% CI 8.8–10.9).
  - GA: 9.3 months (95% CI 8.7–NA).
  - AA: not reached (95% CI 8.8–NA), though number of AA patients was very small and many switched to paclitaxel.
- PFS and OS by UGT1A1*28 (TA6/6 vs TA6/7 vs TA7/7) were similar; no significant differences.
- Combined allele analyses (single vs double variant alleles across *6 and *28) also showed no significant efficacy differences.
- Univariable and multivariate Cox analyses:
  - UGT1A1*6 and UGT1A1*28 were not associated with PFS or OS.
  - Independent prognostic factors for OS were diffuse-type Lauren classification (worse prognosis) and having had prior surgery (better prognosis).

Toxicity outcomes and pharmacogenetic signal:
- UGT1A1*28:
  - No significant association with diarrhea, neutropenia, leukopenia, thrombocytopenia, or anemia (all p > 0.1).
- UGT1A1*6:
  - Significant association with key irinotecan toxicities despite genotype-based dose adjustment:
    - Delayed diarrhea: p = 0.000.
    - Leukopenia: p = 0.003.
    - Neutropenia: p = 0.000.
  - Toxicities increased stepwise from GG → GA → AA.
- Grade 3–4 toxicity rates by UGT1A1*6 (from Table 3 and text):
  - Diarrhea:
    - GG: 2%.
    - GA: 23%.
    - AA: 100%.
  - Leukopenia:
    - GG: 19%.
    - GA: 31%.
    - AA: 100%.
  - Neutropenia:
    - GG: 24%.
    - GA: 31%.
    - AA: 100%.
- Even with a 40% irinotecan dose reduction, all AA patients who received irinotecan experienced severe hematologic and/or gastrointestinal toxicity; in 5 of 8 AA patients, treatment had to be switched to paclitaxel. Three additional AA patients were placed on paclitaxel alone up front due to anticipated risk.
- Thrombocytopenia and anemia were not significantly linked to either *6 or *28 genotype.

Interpretation and pharmacogenomic implications:
- In this East Asian cohort, UGT1A1*6—rather than *28—was the key determinant of irinotecan-related delayed diarrhea and myelosuppression.
- Dose-reduced irinotecan in GA carriers achieved PFS and OS comparable to full-dose irinotecan in GG patients, but GA patients still had more toxicity than GG despite the 20% reduction.
- Homozygous UGT1A1*6 (AA) patients had excessive severe toxicity even at 40% dose reduction; most required switching to paclitaxel, but their survival was not obviously inferior after that switch (though numbers are very small and estimates unstable).
- Overall, genotype-guided irinotecan dosing by UGT1A1*6 allowed:
  - Maintenance of similar survival across *6 genotypes when AA patients were promptly switched to paclitaxel.
  - Marked differentiation of toxicity risk, highlighting AA as a very high-risk group for irinotecan.

Clinical take-home points for pharmacogenomics:
- Pre-treatment UGT1A1*6 testing is clinically useful in Chinese/East Asian gastric cancer patients being considered for irinotecan:
  - GG: full-dose irinotecan is reasonable; toxicity profile acceptable.
  - GA: use dose-reduced irinotecan with careful monitoring; toxicity still higher than GG.
  - AA: irinotecan is likely unsuitable even at substantially reduced dose; consider alternative agents such as paclitaxel instead of irinotecan.
- UGT1A1*28 testing adds little for toxicity prediction in this East Asian setting, consistent with prior data that *6 is the dominant functional variant for irinotecan in Asians.
- The study supports moving toward UGT1A1*6-guided personalization of irinotecan but underscores the need for larger, ideally prospective, trials and better dosing strategies for GA patients, who remain at elevated risk despite preemptive dose reduction.

Limitations:
- Retrospective, single-center, small sample size—especially very few AA patients.
- No non-genotyped control arm and no pure paclitaxel control group.
- Patients with AA genotype were partially or entirely switched to paclitaxel, confounding direct comparisons of efficacy between genotypes under irinotecan.

Overall conclusion:
- Individualized irinotecan dosing guided by UGT1A1*6 is feasible and appears to balance efficacy and tolerability for non-AA patients with advanced gastric cancer.
- UGT1A1*6 AA homozygotes experience prohibitive toxicity despite dose reduction and are poor candidates for irinotecan; paclitaxel is a more appropriate second-line choice in this genotype group.

The administration of intravenous irinotecan occurred every 3 weeks, with the selection of irinotecan dosage based on the polymorphism of *UGT1A1**6 gene. This gene was categorized into 3 groups: *UGT1A1**6 wild-type (GG type) with a dosage of 125 mg/m^2^, d1, d8, *UGT1A1**6 mutant heterozygosity (GA type) with a dosage of 100 mg/m^2^, d1, d8 and *UGT1A1**6 homozygosity mutation (AA type) with a dosage of 75 mg/m^2^, d1, d8 or paclitaxel 125 mg/m^2^, d1, d8.

Patients with *UGT1A1*6* or *UGT1A1*28* genetype showed no significant difference in thrombocytopenia and hemoglobin reduction. In addition, there were no significant differences in diarrhea (*p *= 0.136), neutropenia (*p *= 0.991), and leukopenia (*p *= 0.857) in *UGT1A1*28* subgroups. However, diarrhea (*p *= 0.000), neutropenia (*p *= 0.000), and leukopenia (*p *= 0.003) were significantly different among *UGT1A1*6* subgroups ([Table 3](#table3-15330338241236658)).

var_drug_ann.Variant/Haplotypes: CYP2D6 poor metabolizer, CYP2D6 intermediate metabolizer
var_drug_ann.Notes: In 257 children ≤18 years on risperidone ≥4 weeks, CYP2D6 poor/intermediate metabolizers (n=33) had adverse events in 15/33 (46%) vs 61/224 (27%) in normal/ultrarapid metabolizers (P=0.04). Multivariate logistic regression adjusting for age, sex, race, and initial risperidone dose showed increased AE risk in poor/intermediate metabolizers: adjusted OR 2.4 (95% CI 1.1–5.1, P=0.03).
var_drug_ann.Sentence: CYP2D6 poor metabolizer and CYP2D6 intermediate metabolizer are associated with increased risk of adverse events to risperidone in children with various psychiatric indications as compared to CYP2D6 normal metabolizer and CYP2D6 ultrarapid metabolizer.
var_drug_ann.Population Phenotypes or diseases: Disease:psychiatric and behavioral disorders (e.g., aggression, autism, ADHD)
Citations: For analysis, the 257 individuals were grouped as poor/intermediate metabolizers (n=33, 13%) and normal/ultrarapid metabolizers (n=224, 87%). AEs were more common in poor/intermediate versus normal/ultrarapid metabolizers (15/33, 46% vs. 61/224, 27%, P=0.04). In multivariate analysis adjusting for age, sex, race, and initial dose, poor/intermediate metabolizers had increased AE risk (adjusted odds ratio 2.4, 95% confidence interval 1.1-5.1, P=0.03).
Children with CYP2D6 poor or intermediate metabolizer phenotypes are at greater risk for risperidone AEs.

This study demonstrates that children who are CYP2D6 poor or intermediate metabolizers have increased incidence of AEs during risperidone treatment, with consistent results in both univariate and multivariate analyses.

PMC6435416.summary:
Objective:
To determine whether CYP2D6 metabolizer status is associated with the risk of adverse events (AEs) from risperidone in children and adolescents, and to explore the potential clinical value of pre-emptive CYP2D6 genotyping.

Design and population:
- Retrospective cohort using BioVU, a de-identified DNA biobank linked to electronic health records at Vanderbilt University Medical Center.
- Inclusion: children ≤18 years with ≥4 weeks of risperidone exposure and available, non-compromised DNA.
- Exclusion: care primarily outside VUMC, insufficient dosing/follow-up data, or genetically ambiguous CYP2D6 phenotype.
- Final analyzed cohort: 257 pediatric patients (median age 8.3 years; 73% male; 84% White).

CYP2D6 genotyping and phenotype assignment:
- Next-generation sequencing (Kailos TargetRich PGx panel) plus long-range PCR for copy number variation.
- Star-allele calling followed by phenotype categorization (poor, intermediate, normal, ultrarapid metabolizers) according to standard activity-based schemes.
- Distribution: 15 poor (6%), 18 intermediate (7%), 218 normal (85%), 6 ultrarapid (2%).
- For analysis, poor + intermediate were grouped ("reduced function"), and normal + ultrarapid were grouped ("normal/increased function"), due to small subgroup sizes and some ambiguous CNV cases being excluded (13 patients).

Exposure and outcome definitions:
- Risperidone exposure: any use ≥4 weeks; median starting dose 0.5 mg/day (IQR 0.5–1 mg/day); indications primarily behavioral (e.g., aggression, behavioral problems, irritability, agitation, self-injury), often comorbid with autism, ADHD, seizure disorders, etc.
- Primary outcome: any AE attributed to risperidone in the EHR (by clinician or caregiver report, observation, or lab change). No formal causality assessment; any temporally associated AE documented as risperidone-related was counted.
- Detailed AE characterization (type, timing, dose at AE, management changes) was obtained via blinded manual chart review.

Adverse events – frequency and types:
- 76 of 257 patients (30%) experienced at least one AE; 104 total AE episodes across 20 AE types.
- Most common AEs:
  - Weight change/weight gain (~9%).
  - Sedation (~6%).
  - Extrapyramidal symptoms (EPS; ~6%).
- AE rates by metabolic phenotype:
  - Poor: 5/15 (33%) with AEs.
  - Intermediate: 10/18 (56%).
  - Normal: 58/218 (27%).
  - Ultrarapid: 3/6 (50%).

Association of CYP2D6 phenotype with AEs:
- Grouped comparison: poor/intermediate (n=33) vs normal/ultrarapid (n=224).
- Unadjusted AE rates:
  - Poor/intermediate: 15/33 (46%).
  - Normal/ultrarapid: 61/224 (27%).
  - P = 0.04.
- Multivariable logistic regression (primary analysis):
  - Outcome: occurrence of any AE.
  - Main predictor: poor/intermediate vs normal/ultrarapid metabolizer.
  - Covariates: age at risperidone start, sex, race, initial risperidone dose.
  - Adjusted odds ratio for AE in poor/intermediate vs normal/ultrarapid: OR 2.4 (95% CI 1.1–5.1), P = 0.03.
- No significant differences in demographics, comorbidities, indications, or baseline dosing between metabolizer groups, suggesting the genotype–AE association is not explained by these factors.

Other factors associated with AEs:
- In univariate analyses (independent of CYP2D6 status):
  - Race, aggression, and self-injurious behaviors were associated with higher AE rates.
  - These associations were not clearly independent of other variables in multivariable models that included CYP2D6 status.

Impact of CYP2D6 inhibitors:
- Among normal/ultrarapid metabolizers (n=224), 20 (9%) were taking ≥1 strong CYP2D6 inhibitor concurrently.
- AE rates:
  - With inhibitor: 6/20 (30%).
  - Without inhibitor: 55/204 (27%).
  - P = 0.8.
- Adjusted analysis in normal/ultrarapid group (controlling for age, sex, race, dose):
  - Concomitant strong CYP2D6 inhibitor: OR 1.2 (95% CI 0.4–3.3), P = 0.7.
- Interpretation: In this cohort, measured clinically significant AE risk was driven more by CYP2D6 genotype than by strong inhibitor co-medication.

Interpretation in context of risperidone pharmacology:
- Risperidone is primarily metabolized by CYP2D6 to 9-hydroxyrisperidone (paliperidone), an active metabolite.
- Poor and intermediate metabolizers have reduced CYP2D6 activity, leading to higher parent risperidone exposure and altered risperidone/9-hydroxyrisperidone ratios, which may increase risk for certain AEs (weight gain, EPS, sedation, etc.).
- Prior pediatric data have been inconsistent due to small numbers, differing AE definitions, and different genotyping panels, but several studies converge on increased risk of weight gain and potentially other AEs in patients with reduced CYP2D6 function.

Strengths:
- Relatively large pediatric cohort (n=257) for risperidone pharmacogenetics.
- Comprehensive CYP2D6 genotyping with CNV characterization.
- Blinded manual AE ascertainment from detailed EHR review.
- Adjustment for key clinical covariates (age, sex, race, starting dose) in regression.

Limitations:
- Single-center retrospective study; limited generalizability.
- AE capture relies on documentation quality; no standardized AE rating scales or prospective causality assessment.
- Small numbers of poor (n=15), intermediate (n=18), and ultrarapid (n=6) metabolizers; power was insufficient to analyze each phenotype class separately or to precisely characterize specific AE patterns in ultrarapid metabolizers.
- Many patients were on multiple concomitant medications; while no major confounding was detected statistically, residual confounding by co-therapy or underlying illness severity is possible.

Clinical implications for pharmacogenomics:
- CYP2D6 poor and intermediate metabolizer phenotypes approximately doubled the adjusted risk of any risperidone-related AE compared with normal/ultrarapid metabolizers.
- About one-third of pediatric risperidone users in this cohort experienced at least one AE, underscoring the overall need for close monitoring.
- While no CPIC or other formal dosing guideline yet exists for risperidone based on CYP2D6, this and prior data support the following genotype-informed considerations:
  - CYP2D6 poor or intermediate metabolizers:
    - Consider alternative antipsychotic or mood stabilizing agents that are less dependent on CYP2D6 metabolism where clinically appropriate.
    - If risperidone is used, start at a lower dose and titrate more slowly.
    - Implement heightened surveillance for metabolic AEs (weight, BMI, lipids, glucose), hyperprolactinemia, and movement disorders; counsel families regarding increased AE risk.
  - CYP2D6 ultrarapid metabolizers:
    - Data remain limited and conflicting; some evidence suggests risk for prolactin-related AEs due to higher paliperidone exposure, but this was not seen here, likely due to small numbers.
    - Increased vigilance is still warranted until larger studies clarify risk patterns.
- For high-risk pediatric populations (e.g., overweight/obese patients, those with neurologic comorbidities, or those where AEs would be particularly problematic), pre-prescription CYP2D6 testing may help guide drug choice, dosing, and monitoring intensity.

Overall conclusion:
This study provides evidence that reduced CYP2D6 function (poor or intermediate metabolizer phenotype) in children and adolescents is associated with a significantly higher risk of risperidone-attributed adverse events, independent of age, sex, race, and starting dose. Genotype-guided selection and dosing of risperidone, along with more intensive AE monitoring in reduced-function CYP2D6 phenotypes, is a reasonable strategy, and larger prospective studies are warranted to refine and standardize pharmacogenomic guidance for pediatric risperidone therapy.
PMC6435416.title: CYP2D6 genotype and adverse events to risperidone in children and adolescents

var_pheno_ann.Notes: In multivariate analysis adjusting for age, sex, race, and initial risperidone dose, CYP2D6 poor/intermediate metabolizers had increased adverse event risk compared to normal/ultrarapid metabolizers (adjusted OR 2.4, 95% CI 1.1-5.1, P=0.03). Overall, 5/15 (33%) poor metabolizers experienced AEs versus 58/218 (27%) normal and 3/6 (50%) ultrarapid metabolizers.
var_pheno_ann.Sentence: CYP2D6 poor metabolizers Are associated with increased risk of Adverse Events when treated with risperidone in children with various psychiatric indications.
Citations: "For analysis, the 257 individuals were grouped as poor/intermediate metabolizers (n=33, 13%) and normal/ultrarapid metabolizers (n=224, 87%). AEs were more common in poor/intermediate versus normal/ultrarapid metabolizers (15/33, 46% vs. 61/224, 27%, P=0.04). In multivariate analysis adjusting for age, sex, race, and initial dose, poor/intermediate metabolizers had increased AE risk (adjusted odds ratio 2.4, 95% confidence interval 1.1-5.1, P=0.03)."
"Children with CYP2D6 poor or intermediate metabolizer phenotypes are at greater risk for risperidone AEs."
"In total 5/15 (33%) poor, 10/18 (56%) intermediate, 58/218 (27%) normal, and 3/6 (50%) ultrarapid metabolizers experienced AEs."

var_pheno_ann.Notes: Poor and intermediate metabolizers were analyzed together; 10/18 (56%) intermediate metabolizers experienced AEs. Combined poor/intermediate metabolizers had higher AE rate than normal/ultrarapid metabolizers (46% vs. 27%, P=0.04; adjusted OR 2.4, 95% CI 1.1-5.1, P=0.03).
var_pheno_ann.Sentence: CYP2D6 intermediate metabolizers Are associated with increased risk of Adverse Events when treated with risperidone in children with various psychiatric indications.
Citations: In total 5/15 (33%) poor, 10/18 (56%) intermediate, 58/218 (27%) normal, and 3/6 (50%) ultrarapid metabolizers experienced AEs. ... In univariate analysis, AEs were more common among poor/intermediate metabolizers than normal/ultrarapid metabolizers (15/33, 46% vs. 61/224, 27%, *P*=0.04) ([Table 2](#T2)).

In multivariate analysis, the risk for AEs, after adjustment for age, sex, race, and initial risperidone dose was higher for poor/intermediate metabolizers compared to normal/ultrarapid metabolizers (adjusted odds ratio (OR) 2.4, 95% confidence intervals (CI) 1.1-5.1, *P* =0.03), ([Figure 1](#F1)).

Children with CYP2D6 poor or intermediate metabolizer phenotypes are at greater risk for risperidone AEs. Pre-prescription genotyping could identify this high-risk subset for an alternate therapy, risperidone dose reduction, and/or increased monitoring for AEs.

var_drug_ann.Notes: The admixture-adjusted pharmacogenetic algorithm incorporating CYP2C9, VKORC1 (rs9923231), CYP4F2*3, NQO1*2, and admixture predicted 70% of warfarin dose variance in the derivation cohort (R2 = 0.70, MAE = 0.72 mg/day) compared with 60% (MAE = 0.99 mg/day) for a clinical algorithm excluding genotypes and admixture. The model also predicted 58–59% of dose variance in an external validation cohort, with lower MAE and bias than IWPC and Lenzini algorithms.
var_drug_ann.Sentence: Combined carriage of pharmacogenetic variants in CYP2C9, VKORC1, CYP4F2 and NQO1 is associated with altered warfarin maintenance dose requirements and improved predictability of dose refinement in Caribbean Hispanic patients with thromboembolic disorders as compared to dosing based on clinical factors alone.

Citations: Overall, this admixture-adjusted pharmacogenetic model in Caribbean Hispanics contained thirteen significant ‘explanatory’ variables. These independent predictors explained more than two-thirds of the observed variance in the therapeutic warfarin dose (R^2^ = 70%; MAE = 0.72mg/day; MSE = 0.99; p< 0.001), which is better than that of a clinical non-genetic algorithm in the same derivation cohort (R^2^ = 60%; MAE = 0.99mg/day; MSE = 1.26).

The stepwise regression analysis yielded the following PGt algorithm to predict warfarin doses in Hispanic Puerto Ricans (as seen in [Fig 2](#pone.0145480.g002)):

| WarfarinDose(mgday)=[3.2463−(0.0181∙Age)+(0.4246∙D1)+(0.5157∙tINR)−(1.419∙INRD3)−(0.2450∙CYP2C9*2)−(0.5442∙CYP2C9*3)−(1.00∙CYP2C9*8)−(0.3793∙VKORC1GA)−(0.8958∙VKORC1AA)+(0.5602∙CYP4F2*3)+(0.3457∙NQO1*2)−(0.7948∙Amiodarone)−(0.0932∙Admixture)] | (1) |

As can be observed, our pharmacogenetic model predicted 59% of the variance in warfarin dose when externally validated in 55 genotyped individuals from the independent Hartford’s patient cohort (MAE = 0.89 mg/day, 24% mean bias). On the contrary, the two others reference PGt algorithms showed poorer dose predictability in this independent cohort. … On the other hand, the clinical algorithm that excluded genotypes and admixture only accounted for 50% of dose variability in this independent cohort (MAE = 1.34 mg/day, 34% mean bias, [Fig 3D](#pone.0145480.g003)).

PMC4706412.summary:
This study develops and externally validates a warfarin *dose‑refinement* algorithm specifically for Caribbean Hispanics that uniquely incorporates both pharmacogenetics and individual genomic admixture.

Design and population
- Retrospective derivation cohort: 255 largely male (99.6%), mostly self‑identified Hispanic White warfarin‑treated outpatients from the VA Caribbean Healthcare System (San Juan, Puerto Rico), all with stable maintenance doses and in‑range INR.
- External validation cohort: 55 Puerto Rican patients from Hartford Hospital (more females, somewhat younger).
- All had blood drawn for genotyping and ancestry analysis; clinical data and warfarin dose/INR came from the electronic record.

Genetics and admixture
- Comprehensive genotyping of key warfarin pharmacogenes: CYP2C9, VKORC1, CYP4F2, NQO1, EPHX1 plus a broader physiogenomic/ancestry SNP panel.
- High prevalence of functional variants:
  - CYP2C9: ~30% carried at least one decreased‑function allele, including alleles common in Europeans (*2, *3) and African‑ancestry alleles (*5, *6, *8, *11). Rare promoter variants linked to *8 were also observed.
  - VKORC1 −1639G>A: ~62% carriers (GA or AA).
  - CYP4F2*3: allele frequency 0.11; ~20% carriers.
  - NQO1*2: allele frequency 0.10; ~18% carriers.
  - A rare VKORC1 V45A resistance variant and H7 resistance haplotypes were identified in a few subjects.
- Ancestry proportions (European, West African, Native American) were estimated using STRUCTURE on 332 ancestry‑informative SNPs. Many individuals showed substantial three‑way admixture.
- Native American ancestry was associated with higher frequency of low‑dose requirements (<3 mg/day).

Model development (dose refinement after day 3–4)
- Outcome: stable therapeutic warfarin maintenance dose (mg/day).
- Predictors evaluated: demographic (age, body size, gender), clinical (indication, comorbidities, co‑medications, smoking, diet, day‑1–3 doses, INR at day 3, target INR), genetics (CYP2C9, VKORC1, CYP4F2*3, NQO1*2, EPHX1 variants), and an admixture index (categorical: European, Native American, African, admixed).
- Final multiple linear regression (stepwise) model included 13 predictors:
  - Age (lower dose with older age)
  - Initial dose (D1)
  - Target INR (tINR)
  - Dose‑adjusted INR on day 3 (INR/D3)
  - CYP2C9*2, *3, *8 carrier status
  - VKORC1 −1639 GA and AA
  - CYP4F2*3
  - NQO1*2
  - Admixture index (admixed status associated with lower dose)
  - Amiodarone co‑therapy

Key effect directions (per variant or covariate):
- CYP2C9 decreased‑function alleles (*2, *3, *8): 7–31% lower dose per allele (combined ~18% decrease per variant overall).
- VKORC1 −1639 A allele: ~13% lower dose per A allele.
- CYP4F2*3: ~17% higher dose per allele.
- NQO1*2: ~10% higher dose per allele (borderline significance).
- Admixed ancestry category: ~7% lower dose.
- Each 0.25‑unit increase in INR/D3: ~11% lower final dose.
- Age: ~5% lower dose per decade.

Performance in derivation cohort
- Admixture‑adjusted pharmacogenetic refinement model:
  - R² = 0.70 (70% dose variance explained)
  - MAE = 0.72 mg/day; mean absolute percentage error ~14%
- Clinical (non‑genetic, no admixture) model using the same structure but excluding genotypes and admixture:
  - R² = 0.60
  - MAE = 0.99 mg/day
- Compared with published models applied to this Caribbean Hispanic cohort:
  - Lenzini et al. refinement model R² ≈ 0.34, MAE ≈ 1.33 mg/day.
  - IWPC initiation algorithm R² ≈ 0.27, MAE ≈ 1.20 mg/day.
- By dose strata (derivation cohort):
  - Low dose (≤3 mg/day): pharmacogenetic model R² 63%, MAE 0.51 vs clinical model R² 50%, MAE 1.22; Lenzini and IWPC both markedly worse.
  - Intermediate (>3–<7 mg/day): pharmacogenetic R² 50%, MAE 0.61 vs clinical R² 45%, MAE 0.83.
  - High (≥7 mg/day): pharmacogenetic R² 20%, MAE 1.53 vs clinical R² 2%, MAE 1.53; Lenzini and IWPC performed poorly.

Clinical classification (derivation cohort)
- “Ideal dose” defined as prediction within ±20% of actual stable dose (~±1 mg/day around a 5 mg reference dose).
- Among the highest‑risk patients (≤3 mg/day or ≥7 mg/day), the admixture‑adjusted pharmacogenetic model gave ideal dosing in 54.5% vs:
  - 29% with the clinical non‑genetic algorithm
  - 34% with Lenzini
  - 24.7% with IWPC (all p<0.001 vs pharmacogenetic model).
- For intermediate‑dose patients (3–7 mg/day), ideal dosing:
  - 77% for admixture‑adjusted pharmacogenetic vs
  - 61% clinical
  - 39% Lenzini
  - 62% IWPC (p<0.001 for each comparison vs pharmacogenetic model).
- Overall, the new model gave ideal doses in ~70% of patients, with ~11% underestimates and 19% overestimates, outperforming both prior pharmacogenetic algorithms and the clinical model.

External validation (55 Puerto Rican patients in Hartford)
- Admixture‑adjusted pharmacogenetic model:
  - R² ≈ 0.58–0.59 (the paper reports 58–59%)
  - MAE = 0.89 mg/day
  - Mean bias ≈ 24%.
- Comparators:
  - IWPC: R² = 0.39, MAE = 1.60, bias 34%.
  - Lenzini: R² = 0.27, MAE = 1.62, bias 29%.
  - Clinical non‑genetic model: R² = 0.50, MAE = 1.34, bias 34%.

Interpretation and implications
- This is the first warfarin dosing model to explicitly incorporate an admixture measure derived from ancestry‑informative markers, rather than self‑reported race/ethnicity, in an admixed Hispanic population.
- The inclusion of:
  - non‑European CYP2C9 alleles (notably *8 and promoter variants linked to it),
  - “resistant” CYP4F2*3 and NQO1*2 alleles, and
  - individual admixture metrics
  significantly improves dose prediction compared with: 
  - a purely clinical model, and
  - existing pharmacogenetic models trained primarily in Europeans.
- Admixture itself contributes a modest fraction of R² (<1%) but corresponds to a clinically non‑trivial 7% dose reduction in admixed individuals and likely helps correct for population stratification that would otherwise distort genotype–dose relationships.
- INR/dose on day 3 captures much of the phenotypic warfarin sensitivity (including VKORC1 effects), but genetic factors, particularly CYP2C9, still significantly improve predictions after INR data are available, supporting ongoing value of genotyping beyond initiation.
- The model is especially advantageous in low‑ and intermediate‑dose groups and in carriers of high‑risk or rare variants, where inaccurate dosing is more likely to lead to high INRs and bleeding.
- Findings underscore the limitations of “one‑size‑fits‑all” pharmacogenetic algorithms derived in Europeans when applied to highly admixed populations and argue for ancestry‑aware, population‑specific approaches.

Limitations
- Single‑center derivation cohort, predominantly older male veterans.
- Retrospective observational design; not a randomized trial of genotype‑guided vs standard dosing.
- Admixture index was coded categorically rather than using continuous ancestry proportions in the final regression.
- Genotype and admixture turnaround times (2–3 days) mean the algorithm is for *refinement after day ~4*, not for initial dosing.

Clinical outlook
- The authors are launching a prospective, multicenter randomized trial in Caribbean Hispanics (NCT02345356) to test whether this admixture‑adjusted pharmacogenetic refinement algorithm improves clinical outcomes (e.g., bleeding, time in therapeutic range) versus standard care.
- If validated, such ancestry‑informed pharmacogenomic dosing could reduce warfarin‑related adverse events and dosing disparities in Caribbean Hispanics and potentially other admixed Latino populations.

In essence, this work shows that in Caribbean Hispanics, a warfarin dose‑refinement algorithm that integrates CYP2C9, VKORC1, CYP4F2, NQO1, early INR response, and individual admixture provides substantially better and more clinically useful dose predictions than existing clinical or pharmacogenetic tools built in less admixed populations.
PMC4706412.title: A Novel Admixture-Based Pharmacogenetic Approach to Refine Warfarin Dosing in Caribbean Hispanics

var_pheno_ann.Notes: In the admixture-adjusted pharmacogenetic refinement model, each CYP2C9*2 variant allele was associated with a 7% reduction in therapeutic warfarin dose (partial regression coefficient -0.245, p=0.014).

| WarfarinDose(mgday)=[3.2463−(0.0181∙Age)+(0.4246∙D1)+(0.5157∙tINR)−(1.419∙INRD3)−(0.2450∙CYP2C9*2)−(0.5442∙CYP2C9*3)−(1.00∙CYP2C9*8)−(0.3793∙VKORC1GA)−(0.8958∙VKORC1AA)+(0.5602∙CYP4F2*3)+(0.3457∙NQO1*2)−(0.7948∙Amiodarone)−(0.0932∙Admixture)] | (1) |

Moreover, this covariate was associated with a 13% reduction in the therapeutic warfarin dose per number of A alleles. There are 18% heterozygous (G/A) for the *CYP4F2**3 allele (95%CI: 0.14–0.23) and 2.4% homozygous (A/A) for this variant allele (95%CI: 0.01–0.05); whereas, about 15.7% of patients carried the C/T heterozygous genotype for the *NQO1**2 SNP (95%CI: 0.12–0.21) and 2% were double carriers (T/T) of this variant (95%CI: 0.007–0.05).

Notably, *CYP4F2**3 and *NQO1**2 variants were independently associated with a 17% and 10% increase of the dose per variant allele, respectively; whereas, the admixed status of the admixture index decreases the dose by 7%.

Citations: In this systematic review and meta-analysis of 6 studies involving 322 patients with SCARs, significant associations were identified between the HLA-A*11:01, HLA-B*13:01, HLA-B*15:02, HLA-B*38:02, and HLA-C*08:01 genotypes and SMX/CTX-induced SCARs.

The results of this systematic review and meta-analysis suggest that multiple HLA alleles (HLA-A*11:01, HLA-B*13:01, HLA-B*15:02, HLA-B*38:02, and HLA-C*0801) are associated with SMX/CTX-induced SCARs.

Subgroup analyses by type of SCARs, including SJS/TEN and DRESS, using HIV-positive patients and controls are presented in eTable 6 in Supplement 1. In the SCAR group, positive significant associations were found in HLA-A*11:01 (OR, 2.43; 95% CI, 1.10-5.34), HLA-B*07:05 (OR, 5.37; 95% CI, 1.17-24.70), HLA-B*13:01 (OR, 2.61; 95% CI, 1.01-6.73), HLA-B*15:02 (OR, 4.14; 95% CI, 1.44-11.86), HLA-B*38:02 (OR, 4.90; 95% CI, 1.37-17.54), HLA-C*07:27 (OR, 28.38; 95% CI, 1.46-550.96), and HLA-C*08:01 (OR, 7.85; 95% CI, 2.08-29.62) compared with HIV-positive tolerant controls.

var_drug_ann.Notes: In the SJS/TEN subgroup, HLA-B*15:02 carriers had OR 3.09 (95% CI 1.90-5.02) vs healthy controls and OR 3.01 (95% CI 1.56-5.80) vs tolerant controls.
var_drug_ann.Sentence: Genotype HLA-B*15:02 Is Associated with increased risk of Stevens-Johnson syndrome/toxic epidermal necrolysis to cotrimoxazole in Asian patients as compared to HLA-B*15:02 non-carriers.

“Significant associations were identified between the *HLA-A*11:01*, *HLA-B*13:01, HLA-B*15:02, HLA-B*38:02,* and *HLA-C*08:01* genotypes and SMX/CTX-induced SCARs. PMC10993165.summary:
This systematic review and meta-analysis evaluated whether specific HLA alleles are associated with severe cutaneous adverse reactions (SCARs) triggered by sulfamethoxazole (SMX) or cotrimoxazole (CTX). Six case–control studies (322 SCAR cases; 236 SJS/TEN, 86 DRESS; 8448 healthy and 229 drug-tolerant controls) from diverse populations (European, Japanese, Thai, Taiwanese, Malaysian) were included.

Across all SCAR phenotypes, multiple class I HLA alleles showed significant risk associations. Compared with healthy controls, SMX/CTX-induced SCARs were associated with HLA-A*11:01 (OR≈2.2), HLA-B*07:05 (≈2.9), HLA-B*13:01 (≈5.4), HLA-B*15:02 (≈1.9), HLA-B*38:01 (≈4.3), HLA-B*38:02 (≈3.2), HLA-C*03:04 (≈3.3), HLA-C*04:06 (≈3.3), HLA-C*07:27 (≈11.4), and HLA-C*08:01 (≈1.5). Using SMX/CTX-tolerant controls—more relevant for clinical prediction—significant risk was confirmed for HLA-A*11:01 (OR 2.10), HLA-B*13:01 (5.96), HLA-B*15:02 (2.23), HLA-B*38:02 (3.47), and HLA-C*08:01 (2.63).

Phenotype-specific patterns emerged:
- SJS/TEN: strongly associated with HLA-B*15:02 and HLA-B*38:02 versus both healthy and tolerant controls; HLA-B*07:05, B*13:01, B*38:01, C*04:06, C*07:27, and C*08:01 were also associated in healthy-control analyses.
- DRESS: associated with HLA-A*68:01, HLA-B*13:01, HLA-B*38:01, HLA-B*39:01, HLA-C*03:04, and HLA-C*07:27 (vs healthy controls), and with HLA-A*68:01, HLA-B*13:01, and HLA-B*39:01 (vs tolerant controls). HLA-B*13:01 conferred very high risk for DRESS (OR≈24 vs healthy; ≈23 vs tolerant controls) and was linked to both SJS/TEN and DRESS.

Geographic analyses showed that:
- HLA-B*13:01 is a major risk allele in Thai, Malaysian, and Taiwanese cohorts.
- HLA-A*11:01 is implicated in Japanese and Thai patients.
- HLA-B*15:02 and HLA-C*08:01 are particularly relevant in Thais.
- HLA-B*38:02 is important in Taiwanese, and HLA-B*38:01/B*38:02 in Europeans.

In HIV-positive Thai cohorts receiving CTX (largely for Pneumocystis prophylaxis), odds ratios for several alleles (A*11:01, B*07:05, B*13:01, B*15:02, B*38:02, C*07:27, C*08:01) were even higher when compared to HIV-positive tolerant controls, suggesting additive risk in this population.

Mechanistically, the authors discuss that SMX and its reactive metabolite 4-nitro-SMX likely form drug–HLA–peptide complexes that activate specific CD8+ and CD4+ T-cell clones. Structural and functional work in related literature shows SMX/4-nitro-SMX can bind pockets in HLA-B*13:01 and HLA-B*38:02, and that overlapping risk with dapsone hypersensitivity (also linked to HLA-B*13:01) may underlie observed cross-reactivity. TCR usage (e.g., Vβ20-1) and class II HLA-DQ–restricted CD4+ responses may further shape phenotype-specific outcomes (SJS/TEN vs DRESS).

Key limitations include dominance of Southeast Asian cohorts, mixture of SMX vs CTX as culprit drugs, limited tolerant-control data, incomplete phenotype stratification in some studies, and potential confounding by HLA haplotype linkage disequilibrium (e.g., A*11:01–B*15:02–C*08:01 in East Asians).

Clinically, the study supports that multiple HLA alleles—especially HLA-B*13:01, HLA-B*15:02, HLA-B*38:02, HLA-A*11:01, HLA-A*68:01, HLA-B*39:01, and HLA-C*08:01—confer increased risk of SMX/CTX-induced SCARs, with phenotype- and ancestry-specific patterns. While not yet ready for universal guideline-level implementation, these data argue for consideration of pre-prescription HLA screening in high-incidence populations (e.g., Southeast Asians, particularly for HIV-positive individuals on CTX), analogous to carbamazepine–HLA testing, pending further validation and cost-effectiveness analyses.
PMC10993165.title: Human Leukocyte Antigens and Sulfamethoxazole/Cotrimoxazole–Induced Severe Cutaneous Adverse Reactions: A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis

Sulfamethoxazole (SMX) and cotrimoxazole (CTX), a fixed-dose combination of SMX and trimethoprim (TMP) in a 5:1 ratio, are broad-spectrum antibacterial sulfonamides widely used in managing bacterial, fungal, and protozoal infections.^1,2^ Previous investigations have revealed a substantial prevalence of severe cutaneous adverse reactions (SCARs), encompassing Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS), toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN), and drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS), following the administration of SMX or CTX.^1,2,3,4,5,6^

In this systematic review and meta-analysis, we identified significant associations between the *HLA-A*11:01*, *HLA-B*13:01, HLA-B*15:02, HLA-B*38:02,* and *HLA-C*08:01* genotypes and SMX/CTX-induced SCARs in SMX/CTX-tolerant and healthy control groups.

PMC6465603.summary:
Study question and design: This single-center retrospective pharmacogenetic study evaluated whether NUDT15 R139C (rs116855232) and TPMT*3C (rs1142345) variants predict azathioprine (AZA)–induced leukopenia and influence tolerated AZA dose in Chinese patients with autoimmune hepatitis (AIH) and AIH–PBC overlap, many with cirrhosis. Population and treatment: • 149 consecutive Chinese patients with definite/probable AIH or AIH–PBC variant syndrome treated with AZA ≥3 months at West China Hospital (2013–2017). • 70 had AIH–PBC overlap; 81 had cirrhosis at AZA start. • AZA introduced after steroids per EASL guidance; target maintenance 1–2 mg/kg/day. • CBCs closely monitored; leukopenia defined as WBC <3×10⁹/L, or progressive worsening if pre‑existing.
• 13 patients had leukopenia already before AZA (baseline WBC ~2.5×10⁹/L). Genotyping and metabolite measurement: • NUDT15 rs116855232 (C>T; p.Arg139Cys) and TPMT*3C rs1142345 (T>C; p.Leu125Leu) genotyped by PCR + Sanger sequencing. • 6-thioguanine nucleotide (6‑TGN) in RBCs measured by HPLC in 61 patients. Genotype frequencies: • NUDT15: CC 82.6% (123/149), CT 16.1% (24/149), TT 1.3% (2/149); T-allele frequency 9.4%. • TPMT*3C: 3 heterozygotes (TC) and 1 homozygote (CC); risk allele frequency ~1.7%. Incidence and timing of leukopenia: • Overall AZA-induced leukopenia occurred in 12/149 (8.1%). • All leukopenia episodes developed within 60 days of AZA initiation or dose escalation. • No significant differences in baseline age, sex, liver function, disease severity, cirrhosis, splenomegaly, or baseline WBC between those with and without leukopenia. Association of NUDT15 with leukopenia: • Leukopenia by NUDT15 genotype: – CC: 1/123 (0.8%). – CT: 9/24 (37.5%). – TT: 2/2 (100%). • Strong association between T allele and leukopenia: – OR 20.41 (95% CI 7.84–53.13), P < 0.00001. – Dominant model (CT+TT vs CC): OR 89.47 (95% CI 10.78–742.53), P < 0.0001. – Recessive model (TT vs CC+CT): OR 65.48 (95% CI 2.95–1454.21), P = 0.008. • Predictive performance of carrying at least one T allele: sensitivity 91.67%, specificity 89.05%. • Among NUDT15 variant carriers (CT+TT), 11/26 (42.3%) developed AZA-induced leukopenia. • One TT patient with coexisting TPMT wt/risk developed life‑threatening grade 4 myelosuppression within 4 weeks at ~1.1 mg/kg/day; AZA was stopped and mycophenolate mofetil used thereafter. The other TT patient required dose reduction from 0.9 to 0.2 mg/kg/day. Association of TPMT*3C with leukopenia: • No significant association between TPMT*3C genotype and leukopenia (P = 0.283). • Very low allele frequency in this Chinese cohort, consistent with prior Asian data; TPMT explained little of the leukopenia risk. NUDT15, 6‑TGN, and maintenance dose: • 6‑TGN levels (61 patients): – Median (overall): 149.1 pmol/8×10⁸ RBC (range 49.7–1583.4). – NUDT15 CC: 145.3 (87.4–199.0) pmol/8×10⁸ RBC. – NUDT15 CT: 276.6 (150.9–501.0) pmol/8×10⁸ RBC. – P = 0.002 → heterozygotes accumulate significantly more active metabolite at comparable doses. • Among 93 patients in biochemical remission on maintenance AZA: – NUDT15 CC median maintenance dose: 1.23 (0.95–1.53) mg/kg/day. – NUDT15 CT median maintenance dose: 0.96 (0.83–1.19) mg/kg/day. – P = 0.028 → heterozygotes tolerate and require lower AZA doses. • Dose/6‑TGN ratio (AZA dose per unit 6‑TGN) was significantly lower in CT vs CC (0.005 vs 0.007, P = 0.013), reinforcing that CT carriers generate more 6‑TGN per mg of AZA. • 6‑TGN concentration itself did not differ significantly between patients with and without leukopenia (P = 0.149) and was not associated with gender, AZA maintenance dose, or cirrhosis severity. Baseline leukopenia subgroup: • 13 patients started AZA with pre‑existing leukopenia (median WBC 2.48×10⁹/L); – Only 1 was NUDT15 CT; none showed progressive leukopenia on AZA. – Only one stopped AZA due to gastrointestinal side effects, not marrow toxicity. – Median maintenance dose was 1.13 (0.94–1.60) mg/kg/day. • Suggests that, in NUDT15 wild-type patients, pre‑treatment leukopenia from cirrhosis/hypersplenism does not necessarily preclude safe AZA use at standard doses, though this finding needs prospective validation. Biochemical efficacy and NUDT15: • Among 93 patients achieving biochemical remission: – 75 (80.6%) were NUDT15 CC; 17 (18.3%) were CT. – No significant difference in remission rates by genotype (P = 0.361) or time to remission (median 3.0 vs 4.0 months; P = 0.161). • Thus, lowering AZA dose in NUDT15 heterozygotes to avoid leukopenia does not appear to compromise biochemical control in this cohort. Clinical and pharmacogenomic implications: • In this Chinese AIH/AIH–PBC population, NUDT15 R139C—but not TPMT*3C—is the main pharmacogenetic determinant of AZA‑induced leukopenia and tolerated dose. • NUDT15 T‑allele carriers have markedly higher risk of early leukopenia and accumulate more 6‑TGN at any given AZA dose. • For NUDT15 CT patients with AIH or AIH–PBC: – Use a lower AZA maintenance dose ~1 mg/kg/day (or less) as a default target. – Intensively monitor counts in first 2 months; most leukopenia events occur early. • For NUDT15 TT patients, very low starting doses (e.g., 0.1–0.2 mg/kg/day) or alternative immunosuppressants should be strongly considered, given near-universal severe myelosuppression at standard doses. • In East Asian settings, NUDT15 genotyping has higher clinical utility than TPMT for thiopurine safety; nonetheless, combined TPMT+NUDT15 testing is advisable because rare combined defects can be catastrophically toxic. • Standard AZA doses may still be appropriate in patients with cirrhosis or hypersplenism-related leukopenia if they are NUDT15 wild-type, but prospective data are needed. Limitations: • Single-center, modest sample size, rare TT and TPMT*3C variants; confidence intervals are wide for some genotype strata. • Only rs116855232 and TPMT*3C were tested; rarer functional variants may have been missed. • 6‑TGN measured in only ~41% of patients. Overall conclusion: NUDT15 rs116855232 is a strong predictor of AZA-induced leukopenia and dose tolerance in Chinese patients with AIH and AIH–PBC overlap, outperforming TPMT*3C. Heterozygous NUDT15 carriers can generally be treated safely and effectively with lower AZA doses (~1 mg/kg/day), and even in patients with cirrhosis or prior leukopenia, AZA need not be contraindicated if NUDT15 is wild-type. Routine pre‑treatment NUDT15 (and TPMT) genotyping should be incorporated into thiopurine prescribing for this population.
PMC6465603.title: NUDT15 Polymorphism Confer Increased Susceptibility to Thiopurine-Induced Leukopenia in Patients With Autoimmune Hepatitis and Related Cirrhosis

The gene encoding the TPMT enzyme is highly polymorphic, thus leading to varying levels of enzyme activity in different individuals. However, only approximately 20% of leukopenia cases can be explained by TPMT genetic deficiencies. ... Hence, the lack of significance observed for rs1142345 in the present study is likely due to its low prevalence in East Asian populations and the small sample size of our cohort.

The present study showed a 1.7% frequency of the risk TPMT allele in the analyzed population, which is similar to that reported in other studies involving Chinese IBD patients. This TPMT polymorphism is rare in Asian populations, and the lowest frequencies have been observed in Chinese populations (∼0.9%). ... Hence, the lack of significance observed for rs1142345 in the present study is likely due to its low prevalence in East Asian populations and the small sample size of our cohort.
